headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by and welcome to the Fourth Quarter Earnings Report. [Operator Instructions] I'd like to now turn the conference to our host, Vice President of Investor Relations, Mark Kroeger. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by and welcome to the Fourth Quarter Earnings Report. [Operator Instructions] I'd like to now turn the conference to our host, Vice President of Investor Relations, Mark Kroeger. Please go ahead.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Anne, and good morning, everyone. We'll start the conference call today with comments from Ken Lowe, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Joe NeCastro, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Our prepared remarks should take about
componenttext: Thank you, Anne, and good morning, everyone. We'll start the conference call today with comments from Ken Lowe, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Joe NeCastro, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Our prepared remarks should take about 20 minutes, then we'll open it up for questions. Also on the call with us, are John Lansing, Executive Vice President and President of Scripps Networks; and Lori Hickok, Senior Vice President of Finance. Let me remind you, if you prefer to listen on the web, go to scrippsnetworks.com, click on Investor Relations and find the microphone icon on the landing page. An audio archive will be available on our website later today and we'll leave it there for one week, so you can access it at your convenience.Let me remind you that our discussion this morning will contain certain forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from those predicted, and some of the factors that may cause results to differ are set forth in our publicly filed documents including our Form 10-K. With that, I'll turn it over to Ken.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark. Good morning, all. As always, we appreciate you joining us. Without a doubt, 2009 was a momentous year for Scripps Networks Interactive and its shareholders. We ended the year on a high note, achieving solid growth in both advertising and
componenttext: Thank you, Mark. Good morning, all. As always, we appreciate you joining us. Without a doubt, 2009 was a momentous year for Scripps Networks Interactive and its shareholders. We ended the year on a high note, achieving solid growth in both advertising and affiliate fee revenue during the fourth quarter. For the full year, ad sales were even with last year on an apples-to-apples basis which is especially good news, given that we were managing through the worst recession in the generation. Importantly, we also executed on our top strategic priority for 2009, achieving what we set out to accomplish with our affiliate agreement renewals for both Food Network and HGTV. We couldn't be more pleased with the momentum that we're creating. So let me give you a quick rundown of the headlines.During the fourth quarter, we completed our acquisition of Travel Channel, giving us our third fully-distributed basic cable television network and a promising new lifestyle category on which to build. We achieved a significant reset of our affiliate rates, effectively monetizing the value and the ever-growing popularity of Food Network and HGTV. The new and improved rates took effect January 1. We've put into action our plans to expand internationally. We've created promising joint ventures that enable us to leverage our expertise as creators of lifestyle content around the globe. We're exporting the Food Network to Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia and we're about to enter the growing Indian marketplace. We made clear progress toward our debut later this year of the newly branded Cooking Channel, and we expect Cooking to fit comfortably within the 55 million household footprint we created with its predecessor network. The goal of Cooking is to further capitalize on the exploding consumer interest in food as a television programming genre. And perhaps the best news of all, Food Network, HGTV and Travel Channel reached new heights in 2009 with each brand ending the year with record growth in viewership. Now those are some pretty impressive headlines. All in all, an excellent quarter and a good year, especially considering where the economy was at this time last year.As we begin 2010 with our new affiliate rate structure in place, the company is poised for sustainable growth. As for advertising, the marketplace continues to show improvement which puts us in an enviable position when you factor in the audience growth at our flagship brands.At Food Network, we started the new year pretty much where we left off in 2009. Looking at total households in January, the primetime audience grew a very strong 25% over the same period last year. In fact, Food Network was the highest-rated, most-watched network of all of cable in primetime on Sunday, January 3. Two shows led the way that night. The first was the Super Chef Battle: An American Event (sic) [Super Chef Battle: An Iron Chef America Event] from the White House, which drew a whopping 7.6 million viewers and posted a 2.0 rating among adults 25-54. That by far, is a record audience for Food Network. The second show that night was the premiere of a new competition-based show called the Worst Cooks in America. About 4 million people stuck around to watch the premiere episode of Worst Cooks, making it the highest-rated, most-watched premiere in Food Network's history. The show had a 1.3 rating among adults 25-54 that night.Let me pause for just a minute to emphasize a point. Those are absolutely astounding numbers. And don't forget, Food Network was actually dark in many New York area households that night and for three weeks in January. As one of our advertisers told us recently, Food Network has become a power brand. I couldn't agree more. Looking ahead at Food Network, we have some very promising new shows in the pipeline including one called Private Chefs of Beverly Hills which will premiere in April, by the way. We've also responded to viewer demand for a show dedicated to Mexican cuisine, with the premiere last month of Mexican Made Easy. The show airs Saturday mornings during our in-the-kitchen programming block. Lots of really, really good things happening at the Food Network.Over at HGTV, the audience growth that we enjoyed throughout the second half of 2009 has also continued into the new year. Total household viewership in January grew a very healthy 16%, with the average primetime audience topping 1 million viewers a night. HGTV ended 2009 with its highest ever annual primetime ratings, achieving a solid 1.0 rating among total U.S. households. Again, those are incredibly strong numbers.Our programming team at HGTV has done an outstanding job repositioning the network to keep in sync with the times. Our first-time home buyers programming block including great shows like Property Virgins and My First Place have resonated with viewers and provided the network with the lift it needed. Another hit is a relatively new script called Holmes on Homes. Plus, we're getting plenty of mileage out of perennial favorites House Hunters, House Hunters International and in January, the annual HGTV Dream Home Giveaway special. This year, we'll be adding 14 new series at HGTV, including a show called Selling New York that I suspect will be of interest to a lot of folks in the call this morning.We also announced in December that Mark Burnett will be producing season five of HGTV Design Star which will air this summer. Now we're expecting Mark to do for Design Star what he's already done for Survivor and The Apprentice. HGTV is blazing ahead in 2010 and we're expecting big things at the network. At Travel Channel, the news is every bit as good. Travel finished 2009 with its best year ever in primetime and total day ratings and even more important, the median age of the network's audience dropped from 49 to 44.  Hit shows like Man v. Food with Adam Richman, No Reservations with Anthony Bourdain and Ghost Adventures have found true cult followings with younger viewers. The ratings success of Travel is a great story for Scripps Networks Interactive, as we begin to build out our presence in the promising travel programming category.Of course, it's important to remember, we're not just all about television. We're also making great headway, building related content services in the home, food and travel categories across an array of media platforms, and that includes the highly successful Food Network Magazine, which continues to outpace our initial expectations. Accounting subscriptions and single-copy sales, the magazine is reaching a very impressive 1.3 million readers. We've said it before but it bears repeating, our partners at Hearst tell us that this is the biggest new title launch for them since Oprah Magazine. Also in the food category, we continued to lead on the Internet. Foodnetwork.com and Recipezaar continue to be among the top food websites in the country in terms of total unique visitors, page views and time spent on our websites.In the home category, HGTV just announced a new partnership with Serta to create a collection of eco-friendly mattresses, appropriately labeled as the HGTV Green Home Collection by Serta. hgtv.com and diynetwork.com also maintained their leadership positions as valued online destinations for designers, for do-it-yourselfers and more. So, there you have it: Three powerful, fully-distributed lifestyle television networks; three powerful lifestyle content categories; and great content across a full range of media platforms, including the Internet and mobile devices.Scripps Networks Interactive is extraordinarily positioned to deliver value to our viewers, our advertisers, our distribution partners, and importantly, to our shareholders. With that, I'm going to turn it over to Joe who's going to talk how we finished 2009 and then provide a new outlook for 2010, that will include Travel. Joe?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ken. Good morning, everyone. The fourth quarter turned out to be very good for us. Thanks to the improving advertising environment, strong ratings of our flagship networks and continued growth in affiliate revenue. Excluding the Travel Channel, ad
componenttext: Thanks, Ken. Good morning, everyone. The fourth quarter turned out to be very good for us. Thanks to the improving advertising environment, strong ratings of our flagship networks and continued growth in affiliate revenue. Excluding the Travel Channel, advertising revenue grew a very solid 7% during the three-month period, which pushed full-year ad revenue even with 2008 on an apples-to-apples basis.Strong growth in the fourth quarter was due to the healthier ad market and the success we've had in monetizing the audience growth of both Food Network and HGTV. As for affiliate fee revenue, again, x Travel, we were up about 16% in the fourth quarter and finished the year, up about 16%. That was a tad better than the 15% growth we have forecasted at the beginning of the year. It's also worth noting that ad sales from our Lifestyle Media websites grew 10% during the fourth quarter and that positive trend has continued into the New Year. If you'll remember, Internet ad sales were a leading indicator as we entered the recession, so we see this growth as a very good sign for us.Now looking at other full-year results relative to the guidance we've provided. Programming expenses were up about 9%, not including the write-down and excluding Travel. That was in line with our forecast. All other expenses at our Lifestyle Media segment were down slightly from the prior year, as we had predicted. Again, that's on an apples-to-apples basis minus Travel and any one-time items.Capital expenditures finished the year at $91 million, as we continue to work on the expansion of our Knoxville operations facility. The effective tax rate from continuing operations was about 29% for the full year, which was lower than we had anticipated. A number of one-time discreet items, including some favorable adjustments to previously filed tax returns, contributed to the lower rate. Going forward, when you factor in the non-controlling interest for Food Network and Travel Channel, our effective tax rate should be in the 31% to 33% range.And finally in Shopzilla, we ended up at about $31 million in segment profit which was right about where we had guided.Looking at earnings per share, as we noted in the press release, we finished the quarter at $0.52, after you strip out a number of one-time items related to our affiliate renewals, the Travel acquisition, Cooking Channel rebranding and the uSwitch divestiture. To make sure we're all clear, let me quickly run through and size the items that affected net income and EPS. They're also outlined in the press release for you.First, $21 million write-off of Fine Living programming accounted for about $0.07 per share. This was prompted by our announcement during the fourth quarter that we'd be rebranding Fine Living to the Cooking Channel. The write-off includes existing Fine Living programming and commitments that we determined couldn't be used at Cooking or in our other networks. The write-offs show up as an expense on the income statement which is why programming costs were up 25% during the period.Next, about $18 million or $0.08 per share is tied to the Travel Channel acquisition, including both professional fees and financing costs. Our international investments, primarily  the Chello Zone jv accounted for about $0.01.And finally, to support our affiliate renewals, we had about $4 million in one-time marketing and legal expenses that accounted for another $0.02 or so. And if you live in the New York area, you'd probably know that another tranche of these costs will hit in the first quarter as well.The combination of all the one-time items reduced fourth quarter net income by $0.17 a share which was offset by the $0.17 gain we realized on the sale of uSwitch and the $0.05 added back for the tax adjustments. That should get you to the $0.52.So that was 2009. Let's move on to the forecast we provided this morning. I'm sure you noticed that since we're including Travel Channel in our forecast, we've decided to give you a range of actual dollars on Lifestyle Media revenue and expense items, rather than try to relate apples to oranges using a growth rate. We thought this would be a better way to present our guidance for this year.Let's start with affiliate fee revenue for 2010. With the majority of our carriage rights agreements renewed at more attractive rates, total affiliate fee revenue is expected to be in the $530 million to $540 million range with about $100 million of that coming from Travel.As Ken said, we accomplished substantially all that we've set out to accomplish in this very important round of renewals, achieving parity and rate structures between Food Network and HGTV. Rates of both networks also are now more in line with our competitive set. The new rate structure, we believe, more accurately represents the value of these brands for both us and for our distribution partners.Moving to Lifestyle Media expenses including Travel, we expect programming amortization costs to be between $380 million and $400 million and non-programming costs to be within the range of $550 million to $570 million. You'll remember, please, that we cut back dramatically on marketing expenses in 2009.At Shopzilla, we're forecasting segment profit to be $33 million to $35 million which would be a modest improvement from 2009. The performance you saw in 2009 will likely continue through the first half of 2010 with a much, much stronger finish in the back half. One other operating item for 2010. While it's too early to quantify with any precision, we do expect to report losses on our international startups in the year ahead.And finally, we expect capital spending to be in the $95 million to $100 million change. We're on track to finish our Knoxville expansion this year, so starting in 2011, I'd look for a normalized CapEx run rate of about $50 million  to $60 million per year.Before I finish, let me quickly bring you up-to-date on where we are with Travel Channel's integration. At this point, I'd say, we're proceeding very close to plan. We anticipate fully assuming ad sales responsibilities by the end of the first quarter which will tee us up to market the brand in this year's upfront. We also expect to assume technical responsibilities from Discovery in about the same time frame. We lastly expect to assume affiliate sales during the second quarter.A couple more housekeeping notes related to Travel. You'll notice that we did not include the quarterly balance sheet or cash flow statement with this morning's release. That's because we're still working through some of the acquisition accounting. Naturally, we'll have everything ready in time for our 10-K filing in a couple of weeks. Let me highlight a couple of balance sheet items though. First, we ended the year with a cash balance of about $254 million. That includes $181 million we contributed to the Travel Channel joint venture. And our debt balance at year end is $884 million, again all related to the Travel acquisition.Lastly, when we report the first quarter, we intend to provide a quarter-by-quarter pro forma look at Travel to help you with your models and comparisons going forward. With that, operator, we are ready to take questions.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  The first one is coming from Michael Morris [UBS].
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  The first one is coming from Michael Morris [UBS].

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, can you provide us some more color on those renewed contracts that you've entered into, effective the beginning of the year? You made a statement that you see a parity in rate structure now between Food and HGTV. Does that mean that the rates themsel
componenttext: Joe, can you provide us some more color on those renewed contracts that you've entered into, effective the beginning of the year? You made a statement that you see a parity in rate structure now between Food and HGTV. Does that mean that the rates themselves are the same? Does it mean that the escalators are the same? And then, what are you seeing in terms of escalators on those contracts, if you can maybe give us some guidance there? And then in terms of what you reported for Food and HG in the quarter, Food revenue grew at a much higher rate than HG. Both have had very strong ratings, Food a bit stronger. But can you talk a bit more about why Food grew so much higher than HGTV in this quarter?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: As far as rates, let me start by saying, there's a limit on what we can disclose based on our negotiations. But let me give you a little bit of color. The parity comment does refer to rates. We are going to be in the same neighborhood as the other network
componenttext: As far as rates, let me start by saying, there's a limit on what we can disclose based on our negotiations. But let me give you a little bit of color. The parity comment does refer to rates. We are going to be in the same neighborhood as the other network and some of our peer networks. And the terms are, they're multi-year, they're varying terms and not all are going to terminate at the same time. The escalators are a little bit different shape than what we've told you in the past about the HGTV renewals. We did achieve a much larger slug of the growth early on, in the Food renewals. So by and large, we're very, very pleased with how those renewals came out. And as I said, we certainly met our objectives and we actually exceeded our internal expectations for success on the renewals. So I'm going to turn it over to John for the second part of your question.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, the story on Food compared to HGTV is one really where we saw the growth in ratings on Food throughout the full year of 2009, and it gave us three opportunities to improve our estimates going into the ad sales market. We improved on them once. Af
componenttext: Michael, the story on Food compared to HGTV is one really where we saw the growth in ratings on Food throughout the full year of 2009, and it gave us three opportunities to improve our estimates going into the ad sales market. We improved on them once. After the second quarter, we grew them once again in the upfront, and then we grew them yet again going into the fourth quarter for the Scatter business. And as a result, we were able to drive up our average unit rate for Food Network and capture the value of that ratings growth in the fourth quarter in a manner that was measurably higher than HGTV. But thankfully, now that HGTV has caught a wave, having now seen six straight months of audience growth, we're also able to begin pushing the estimates up for HGTV as well.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: And just so I'm clear, Joe, on those rates. For HG and for Food, essentially all of the renewed contracts at this point are at essentially the same per-subscriber rate, is that correct? You said in the same neighborhood?
componenttext: And just so I'm clear, Joe, on those rates. For HG and for Food, essentially all of the renewed contracts at this point are at essentially the same per-subscriber rate, is that correct? You said in the same neighborhood?

componenttextpreview: We're in the same neighborhood. I think that's the way to look at it.
componenttext: We're in the same neighborhood. I think that's the way to look at it.

componenttextpreview: We probably had about $11  million in basis plus there was some foreign currency gains on the balance sheet, which is why you're seeing a gain, it's non-cash. What you're seeing is really some, it's accounting rules that would allow us to take those in wh
componenttext: We probably had about $11  million in basis plus there was some foreign currency gains on the balance sheet, which is why you're seeing a gain, it's non-cash. What you're seeing is really some, it's accounting rules that would allow us to take those in when we wrote off part of the book value at the end of last year.

componenttext: So I sense, you're saying that I can't just tax effect the gain and say that, that's the cash proceeds, or not?

componenttext: No, not exactly. We can give you more on that later if you want.

componenttextpreview: The second item would be on the affiliate fee issue. Joe, it looks like if we take out the $100 million or so for Travel, it looks like about $100 million increment for affiliate fees year-on-year, correct? For the core networks, x Travel.
componenttext: The second item would be on the affiliate fee issue. Joe, it looks like if we take out the $100 million or so for Travel, it looks like about $100 million increment for affiliate fees year-on-year, correct? For the core networks, x Travel.

componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, that's about right. Might be a little more than that.
componenttext: Yes. I think, that's about right. Might be a little more than that.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: But that would seem to suggest that year one, ballparking for all the networks, and I'm assuming that's primarily for HGTV and Food, that's about $0.05 per sub per month, ballpark. If I take $100 million divided by 200 million total households and divide
componenttext: But that would seem to suggest that year one, ballparking for all the networks, and I'm assuming that's primarily for HGTV and Food, that's about $0.05 per sub per month, ballpark. If I take $100 million divided by 200 million total households and divide that by 12, I think that comes out to about $0.05.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Barry, I think you're vastly oversimplifying it. First of all, not all HG subs came up this time. At year end, I think we only had about 50% of the HG subs come up and we have about 75% of Food subs come up and Comcast was not one of the renewals at this
componenttext: Barry, I think you're vastly oversimplifying it. First of all, not all HG subs came up this time. At year end, I think we only had about 50% of the HG subs come up and we have about 75% of Food subs come up and Comcast was not one of the renewals at this time. So the increase per sub was well north of what you calculated.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Last item, any more color you can provide on the ad environment today, given the strength that you exited the fourth quarter with?
componenttext: Last item, any more color you can provide on the ad environment today, given the strength that you exited the fourth quarter with?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: We're continuing to see a very strong scatter marketplace for advertising. Scatter versus scatter is now in the plus territory, in the mid singles and in the mid-teens, higher than upfront business. And so the strength we saw that accelerated through each
componenttext: We're continuing to see a very strong scatter marketplace for advertising. Scatter versus scatter is now in the plus territory, in the mid singles and in the mid-teens, higher than upfront business. And so the strength we saw that accelerated through each of the three months in the fourth quarter carried over into January and continues to look very strong.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: We will now go to Matthew Harrigan. He's with Wunderlich.
componenttext: We will now go to Matthew Harrigan. He's with Wunderlich.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk more about the international angle on -- no pun intended, on the Travel Channel and the competition out of London? The branding is going to be a little bit confused, the potential there, relative to Food and HGTV overseas. And then secondly,
componenttext: Can you talk more about the international angle on -- no pun intended, on the Travel Channel and the competition out of London? The branding is going to be a little bit confused, the potential there, relative to Food and HGTV overseas. And then secondly, can you talk about your over-indexing in the HD homes which is presumably providing some of the thrust for your ratings improvement and maybe that applies particularly to Travel? And then lastly, you've shown us the magazines, that you're able to do some things in media that a lot of other guys can't do right now on the older categories of media. Can you talk about some things like the tabloid and all that, and how you'd be on as-is Internet strategy right now, how that overlays and whether you would expect to perform disproportionately well with some adaptations in the ad areas as well? I know it's a little bit fuzzy, but it seems like you just have so many venues for extending your brand right now.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Look, on the international. I think, we're at a very early stages of thinking about Travel. If we sort of put in priority order the categories that we like for international, I'd say Food is number one, a generalized lifestyle channel, probably branded un
componenttext: Look, on the international. I think, we're at a very early stages of thinking about Travel. If we sort of put in priority order the categories that we like for international, I'd say Food is number one, a generalized lifestyle channel, probably branded under Fine Living is number two. Travel, while it has great international appeal, you correctly point out, has established competitors and other choices in many, many markets. Not the least of which is owned by our good friends at Discovery. So we're proceeding cautiously. One thing we do like is that we do think the programming has great appeal. We are not so concerned that the brand name is taken in large parts of the world. The fact that these two companies did have the same set of parents way back when, and split off at that point, international went one way and domestic one another. We had conversations with the owner there. There are things we might be able to do to get it down the road, but we're not married to that brand globally, partly because we think the programming is more important than the brand and we may actually create other brands, if we think that there's a room for another stand-alone Travel network, globally. But, like I said, we like the programming appeal. It's sort of third on our list of most important priorities globally. But we're going to do our best there and as I said, we're still early days thinking about what we can do with Travel.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Matt, I think what you may be referring to, we do indeed over-index with high-definition audiences and that really is an artifact of the fact that our audiences are in the top five in terms of both young women and upscale younger audiences altogether. And
componenttext: Matt, I think what you may be referring to, we do indeed over-index with high-definition audiences and that really is an artifact of the fact that our audiences are in the top five in terms of both young women and upscale younger audiences altogether. And so to the extent we over-index upscale, I think, that translates into the high-definition viewing and its evidence of the fact that we do well with those audiences. Regarding your question about platforms, when you think about, particularly HGTV and Food, or maybe think more in terms of our two biggest categories, Food and Home, we really have brands and now adding Travel to the mix -- brands that transcend television per se and resonate with audiences on a variety of platforms. And the way we think about it is that we're agnostic as to the platform per se. Rather, we just think about accessing as many consumer touch-points as we possibly can, that resonate with our media content. So we're seeing that happening with the Food Network Magazine. We're seeing it certainly through our Digital businesses. Travel Channel, by the way, has also done a great job in this regard. Their website is up 20% in traffic after their recent redesign. And we just see lot of opportunity going forward to create new revenue streams on top of these relationships we build by way of these massive cable television properties that continue the growth into the future.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Now, we're going to John Janedis. He's with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Now, we're going to John Janedis. He's with Wells Fargo.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, just wanted to follow up on Travel Channel, obviously a lot of pieces here. But can you give it more clarity on both the programming and non-programming expenses for the year? And maybe, can you also, on expense front, talk about incremental expenses
componenttext: Joe, just wanted to follow up on Travel Channel, obviously a lot of pieces here. But can you give it more clarity on both the programming and non-programming expenses for the year? And maybe, can you also, on expense front, talk about incremental expenses related to the Cooking Channel?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: John, this Joe. On the Travel Channel expenses, we're very careful. We don't provide enough information to get people to segment profit by network, and there's a good reason for that. There's just too many allocations involved. In fact, it's pretty early
componenttext: John, this Joe. On the Travel Channel expenses, we're very careful. We don't provide enough information to get people to segment profit by network, and there's a good reason for that. There's just too many allocations involved. In fact, it's pretty early on the Travel Channel. We're not really even fully through our integration process. So to provide specific guidance on expense line items, is premature. I will say this, we absolutely expect that, that the network has the full potential to achieve every bit of margin that the other two fully-distributed networks do, and we're working towards that objective. So I think, I'm going to have to ask you to stay tuned on that one while we work through the transition. I think, as we get a little more clarity there, we can give you some better guidance on margin expectations for Travel Channel as we go forward.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: So can you at least help maybe with just the one-time transition cost then?
componenttext: So can you at least help maybe with just the one-time transition cost then?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Transition cost, again, they are the outcome of our transition plan, which is still somewhat under construction. There are things in there that you would expect. There are some breakage related to the Discovery agreements. There are things that we're goin
componenttext: Transition cost, again, they are the outcome of our transition plan, which is still somewhat under construction. There are things in there that you would expect. There are some breakage related to the Discovery agreements. There are things that we're going to have to put in place. Some infrastructure we're building to adapt the way they operate to the way we operate. And there will be some disruption to that business, and there may even be some real estate implications. So I think, it won't be an insignificant number for the year. But I'm afraid it's a little early to give you a range on that. On the question of Cooking Channel and the transition there, the only transition expense that would sort of not have been covered by the existing Fine Living budget that we had, would've been, call them launch fees or conversion fees that we paid in incentives to the operators to launch the new network for us, so worked with us to launch the new network. And relatively modest fee it will be an increase in expenses there, but it's not going to be significant. You can think in terms of $1 or so that we converted over a very long period of time it will be amortized. So overall, those carriage agreements. So it's not going to be a meaningful change in this year's budget for what we had in place for Fine Living.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe just a follow-up on the international front, if we were thinking about dilution there, in general, would a range or a thought of kind of a few percentage points or low singles be the right range or the right way to think about it?
componenttext: And maybe just a follow-up on the international front, if we were thinking about dilution there, in general, would a range or a thought of kind of a few percentage points or low singles be the right range or the right way to think about it?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you talking about dilution on -- give me the basis of what...
componenttext: Are you talking about dilution on -- give me the basis of what...

componenttext: No, international investment, whether be programming related to Asia or the other things that you're doing that you've announced?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: The other thing, at this point, we have one operation under way and one about to get underway in the Far East. It's again early, but I would tell you that we lost a $0.01 worth in the Chello Zone operation for the various short start-up period. A lot of t
componenttext: The other thing, at this point, we have one operation under way and one about to get underway in the Far East. It's again early, but I would tell you that we lost a $0.01 worth in the Chello Zone operation for the various short start-up period. A lot of that was launch-related and initial marketing campaign that will occur. The big unknown is when do we actually hit the ground in India and the sort of the shape of that business and the timing of a launch of a second network there. And frankly, we haven't even closed on that transaction. We put the announcement out when we reached the sort of term sheet, and we're still waiting for some regulatory approval there. We won't likely close until sometime late in the first quarter. So I hate to dodge this one, but we do have an appetite to continue to invest there, we will. We will be conservative as we always are, but we do expect that we're going to loss some money this year. And as I said out to the earlier question or answer the early question, I think as we get a little more clarity on the plan, especially in India, we'll able to give you a little better guidance on that.

componenttext: It would be very modestly dilutive to the overall, and the others are going to be lifting some. So I think in our view, that's our internal projection. So I think the overall will grow, it'd be slightly dilutive, Travel will be slightly dilutive to the others.

componenttextpreview: Is there any material change year-over-year in your corporate expenses '10 versus '09, like down $50 million to $55 million?
componenttext: Is there any material change year-over-year in your corporate expenses '10 versus '09, like down $50 million to $55 million?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: On an apples-to-apples basis, no, in fact, we expect it to be flat-ish to up, very, very slightly. But our corporate line is where we're carrying the development expenses related to international. So to the extent we do more there, we're more aggressive t
componenttext: On an apples-to-apples basis, no, in fact, we expect it to be flat-ish to up, very, very slightly. But our corporate line is where we're carrying the development expenses related to international. So to the extent we do more there, we're more aggressive there, it will hurt that line item. That said, we will give you -- we'll break that out in our results, let you know exactly how much of the corporate line item is related to international and other developments. So you'll see that.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: And then final question is on minority interest because I think, if I'm not mistaken, cock's [ph] owns the other 35% of Travel, so I would imagine that your minority expense would go from the call at $100 million and Food Network that you don't own and th
componenttext: And then final question is on minority interest because I think, if I'm not mistaken, cock's [ph] owns the other 35% of Travel, so I would imagine that your minority expense would go from the call at $100 million and Food Network that you don't own and then, what can we expect to add to that minority interest line in 2010?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: We think it'll be right around $120 million for 2010 with all in. That's an estimate you can use. Obviously, it's more profitable as us. It was the bigger that number gets.
componenttext: We think it'll be right around $120 million for 2010 with all in. That's an estimate you can use. Obviously, it's more profitable as us. It was the bigger that number gets.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010

componenttext: And next, we'll go to Brian Shipman, he is with Jefferies.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on the margin-related question for media networks, I guess longer-term, bigger picture, where do you see that potential margin moving towards? And then second question related to international, I know it's going to be small this year, bu
componenttext: Just to follow up on the margin-related question for media networks, I guess longer-term, bigger picture, where do you see that potential margin moving towards? And then second question related to international, I know it's going to be small this year, but what percent will international contribute this year and where do you see that going longer-term as well?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Look, longer term on Media and Services, the way we typically think about margin is that it's an outcome of actions that we take to build the brand over time. And we've said many, many times, we don't manage to a margin. That said, as you build affiliate
componenttext: Look, longer term on Media and Services, the way we typically think about margin is that it's an outcome of actions that we take to build the brand over time. And we've said many, many times, we don't manage to a margin. That said, as you build affiliate fee revenue over time, that's margin-enhancing and that will provide upward pressure on the margin over time. But you always have to have overextending[ph] caveat, that we will do what it takes to build for the long-term of the networks and if that means, there's a year where like this year, we're going to restore marketing expenses that were absent last year, that will go in the other direction. I think where you see the margin sit now is obviously very strong, very healthy. It could continue to move up if we did nothing else, but we're not in a business of milking the network. If we want something that's going to be just as strong 10 years from now, we like to take credit for these networks being as strong as ever 15 years after launch. So we're feeling very good about where we are. We will continue to push in the direction we pushed. International, look, I would make sure that we all keep our expectations in check on international. It's a start up for us and we're going to be very prudent the way we like to be on everything. So we're going to try to walk before we run. I would not expect a significant percentage of revenue or even something I would worry about measuring at this point in 2010. I would love to believe that by the end of 2010, we're in a position to say it's going to be -- it'll hit the radar for 2011. But unfortunately, we're a little bit -- we're in that mode where we're a little opportunistic more than we are. Anything else where we're trying to see what opportunities make the most sense and what geographies. And so I don't have a budget in mind for what that ought to be. I think longer-term, our view of international, it should easily hit 10% to 15% of our revenue a few years out. That's sort of our mindset. If we come up with opportunities that are bigger than that or that are more profitable but smaller than that, that could change.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010

componenttext: First, can you give us a sense of what's embedded in your guidance for advertising for 2010? Is it similar to the outlook for the first quarter? You carry that forward? Is it more conservative or more aggressive?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: We're not giving any specific guidance regarding ad performance for 2010, similar to last year. But I can again, comment that the market place continues to be very strong, the scatter marketplace. And as that pricing improves and that combines with our im
componenttext: We're not giving any specific guidance regarding ad performance for 2010, similar to last year. But I can again, comment that the market place continues to be very strong, the scatter marketplace. And as that pricing improves and that combines with our improving ratings, we're seeing our average unit rate for our commercials go up and so the direction is as positive, if not more positive, than the finish in the fourth quarter of '09.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: And then shifting over to ratings, did you guys analyze your performance? Is there a point in time throughout the year that investors should expect the ratings growth to slowdown dramatically because you start to just compare against last year's success o
componenttext: And then shifting over to ratings, did you guys analyze your performance? Is there a point in time throughout the year that investors should expect the ratings growth to slowdown dramatically because you start to just compare against last year's success or is there, as you look at new shows coming on, still more room for growth in these networks through the year?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: No, absolutely more room for growth. That's part and partial the reason why we're investing once again, in more marketing to put behind and support the new launches of these series. As you know, last year, we spent very little on marketing. We relied esse
componenttext: No, absolutely more room for growth. That's part and partial the reason why we're investing once again, in more marketing to put behind and support the new launches of these series. As you know, last year, we spent very little on marketing. We relied essentially on our existing audiences watching longer and more often. And in terms of attracting new audiences, that's the point of investment in marketing and we think our programming teams at all three of our major networks: Travel, HGTV, Food, have an excellent plan going into 2010 and we intend to support that plan, and we expect the results would be positive throughout the year.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, I just wanted to try the new ones, the affiliate fees a little bit further. You said you had a sort of a mix of contracts. And that I think you sort of comment, for the most part you achieved pretty good step ups, right away, early in the
componenttext: And then lastly, I just wanted to try the new ones, the affiliate fees a little bit further. You said you had a sort of a mix of contracts. And that I think you sort of comment, for the most part you achieved pretty good step ups, right away, early in the contract versus your old, the HGTV contracts that you done previously. Were there some contracts that were multiyear step ups? Was it a mix or should we consider all the contracts who had a first-year step up?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: This is John. First of all, we believe the affiliate negotiations were exceptional in terms of the outcome. Actually, well beyond even our greatest expectations. The step up is significant for Food as we hoped it would be, and it was also significant in a
componenttext: This is John. First of all, we believe the affiliate negotiations were exceptional in terms of the outcome. Actually, well beyond even our greatest expectations. The step up is significant for Food as we hoped it would be, and it was also significant in all of our other negotiations. Each negotiation is separate and individual. We can't comment obviously, on the terms. But over the total term of the individual deals going forward, the increase to our bottom line will be substantial in year one and will continue throughout the term.

componenttextpreview: Okay, so there'll be sort of above normally increases perhaps in year two and year three you when you just look at the mix?
componenttext: Okay, so there'll be sort of above normally increases perhaps in year two and year three you when you just look at the mix?

componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: And I think you just confirmed me with a statement but just to be clear, you said that Food was at parity with HGTV, but HGTV also received healthy step ups in these negotiations?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: John, if you could just give us a bit more color on your comments on the advertising markets, specifically what verticals are you seeing particular strength and behind the strong scatter market? I assumed no one's really exercising their options to cancel
componenttext: John, if you could just give us a bit more color on your comments on the advertising markets, specifically what verticals are you seeing particular strength and behind the strong scatter market? I assumed no one's really exercising their options to cancel upfront commitments, if that's correct? And lastly, sorry to make you repeat yourself, but did you say scatter was up mid-single digits versus scatter in Q1 versus up double, scatter in Q4?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Scatter in the first quarter is a mid-single digits higher than the scatter from last year's first quarter. So that's the first scatter-over-scatter pricing growth that we've seen in over four quarters. So that's positive. In terms of the verticals for th
componenttext: Scatter in the first quarter is a mid-single digits higher than the scatter from last year's first quarter. So that's the first scatter-over-scatter pricing growth that we've seen in over four quarters. So that's positive. In terms of the verticals for the first quarter, the leading top six for us include food, consumer product goods, financial, retail, medical and automotive. And then in terms of your question about upfront cancellations, the good news is that we saw really a normalized, meaning very few cancellations for the summer up front going into the fourth quarter. However, we did see some cancellations in the calendar up front which is the upfront cancellations, the good news is that we saw, really a normalized, meaning very few cancellations for the summer upfront going in the first quarter. However, we did see some cancellations in the calendar upfront, which is the upfront business that we booked that is January through December. But we have more than offset those cancellations by a substantial growth in the scatter marketplace. In fact, we think many of those dollars are just re-expressing themselves from calendar upfront through the scatter market itself. And so buy and large, we're thankfully seeing a normalized quarter in terms of cancellations from last summer's upfront and in terms of strength in the scatter marketplace that is continuing to offset any other cancellations that we experienced through the calendar upfront.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the fourth quarter, I assumed in scatter was up over upfront pricing, but scatter was still down year-over-year in Q4?
componenttext: And then in terms of the fourth quarter, I assumed in scatter was up over upfront pricing, but scatter was still down year-over-year in Q4?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: That's exactly right.
componenttext: That's exactly right.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: On the transition of Fine Living, I think you've mentioned it was going to be completed in the second quarter. I guess how long should we assume before we really see a turnaround there with where we can see sort of resumption of revenue growth in that cha
componenttext: On the transition of Fine Living, I think you've mentioned it was going to be completed in the second quarter. I guess how long should we assume before we really see a turnaround there with where we can see sort of resumption of revenue growth in that channel?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Well our ad sales teams are getting a lot of positive feedback regarding the rebranding of Fine Living to the Cooking Channel. The Food category, currently, is the hottest category in cable, both in terms of audience and as you heard, in terms of advertis
componenttext: Well our ad sales teams are getting a lot of positive feedback regarding the rebranding of Fine Living to the Cooking Channel. The Food category, currently, is the hottest category in cable, both in terms of audience and as you heard, in terms of advertiser demand. We have a team that's putting together an exceptional programming plan for the Cooking Channel. It's scheduled to launch on Memorial Day, weekend and the demand is lining up behind it. So not to overstate that and have too much optimism, but I have to tell you, the optimism around here about Cooking and our ability to cross promote Cooking on Food Network, the fact that audience are craving this type of programming and advertisers are looking for it, we feel very good about this rebranding of Fine Living to Cooking that'll occur in the spring.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: And we will now go to Benjamin Swinburne, he is from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we will now go to Benjamin Swinburne, he is from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: On the programming cost outlook and maybe one just sort of on the accounting side and then Ken, a longer-term question. We don't have a cash flow statements, I'm not sure what your cash investment in programming was in '09 versus '08. But when I strip out
componenttext: On the programming cost outlook and maybe one just sort of on the accounting side and then Ken, a longer-term question. We don't have a cash flow statements, I'm not sure what your cash investment in programming was in '09 versus '08. But when I strip out what I think Travel is plus your impairment in the fourth quarter, it seems like your programming cost amortization guidance is sort of 10%, 11% growth in '10 versus '09 on the kind of core networks. And my understanding is it's four-year amortization accelerated depreciation of your cash investments is the way the accounting works. And correct me if I'm wrong, so I was curious if you could just help sync up your cash investment in programming over the last year or two and this growth rate, which I think is sort of flat with '09. I would've expected it to moderate in '10 versus '09, but maybe I'm doing the math wrong or my Travel estimate may be wrong? And then along those lines, Ken, when you think about down the road, if in fact, the broadcasters start to receive retransmissions fees the way they think they will, you can make an argument that the sort of cost of audience growth goes up in general because you've been with competing with broadcasters in many ways instead of had a broken model. And if, in fact, that model gets fixed and there's an influx of billion of dollars of retrends, how does that change, if at all, your investment strategy and content and how you think about spending on your core networks?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll help you out, this is Lori on the programming. Our cash spend is about flat with last year, so you won't see year-over-year from 2009 to 2008 much different. If you take the write-out, right off out for this year, we were up about 9%, which is right
componenttext: I'll help you out, this is Lori on the programming. Our cash spend is about flat with last year, so you won't see year-over-year from 2009 to 2008 much different. If you take the write-out, right off out for this year, we were up about 9%, which is right in with our guidance. Next year, we are planning on being, if you exclude Travel, up 5% to 7%, which we had guided before. So hopefully that helps you get to where you're trying to go. So we are moderating our increased year-over-year on the core networks.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, so then I must be too high on Travel when I'm doing that math.
componenttext: Okay, so then I must be too high on Travel when I'm doing that math.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Sounds like it. And Benjamin, I think what's not being factored into the equation, as much right now, is kind of shifting of some revenue, which you know historically, since retransmission consent launched in the mid-90s and we were pretty much at the fro
componenttext: Sounds like it. And Benjamin, I think what's not being factored into the equation, as much right now, is kind of shifting of some revenue, which you know historically, since retransmission consent launched in the mid-90s and we were pretty much at the front end of that because we cooked the retransmission consent of our 10 television stations and then we coupled that with some other television station groups. So we used that leverage to get HGTV launched and as you know, that was really also a mechanism for getting Food launched. Some of those dollars that went from retransmission to cable networks like ours are now maybe going to be shifting back to the network model. But that comes with NBC, ABC, CBS to a certain degree and Fox's as well, maybe having to shift some revenue internally. So it's not going to be that all this new revenue is going to be created, as much as we're going to see some more chips, some resetting the breaks, which is going to have some upheaval over the coming negotiations. Having said all of that and having just gone through a massive renewal with about 75% of our new Food Network base, it's still going to come down to, in my opinion, quality content that has passionate viewership, passionate engagement from the audience, that has high-quality for the advertising community. So you'll continue to see us invest. I think it's going to be a more competitive environment. I think looking forward, you can actually expect to see some, as I said, not only dollar shifting, but some smaller and less popular cable networks really put under to rest. From our standpoint, there's going to be a lot of movement but I've never felt stronger about our brands. And as John was alluding to earlier, as we see technology and some of the things that are probably going to be happening in the future with TV everywhere, interactivity being enhanced with these set-top boxes, our brands are actually, I think in for great runs and that's why we were thrilled to pick up one more category, the Travel category, if you go to the [ph] the Home category and the Food category. And to paraphrase what John said, our brands really transcend television. So it's great to have those TV brands as popular as they are, but we've never been about just cable networks, we've been about categories.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We have a question from Brian Karimzad, he's with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We have a question from Brian Karimzad, he's with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question on that non-programming expense side, so you had wonderful audience growth last year with a pretty bare bones marketing budget. Any reason why you shouldn't just kind of continue, not necessarily with bare bones, but why you're going full
componenttext: Just a question on that non-programming expense side, so you had wonderful audience growth last year with a pretty bare bones marketing budget. Any reason why you shouldn't just kind of continue, not necessarily with bare bones, but why you're going full open with the marketing spend this year when you seem to do pretty well without that? I'm know you're trying to get some new viewers in, but there's two ways to think about it. I guess, one is that if you had spent more, you would've had that many more viewers. The other is perhaps maybe where you're spending on marketing, wasn't the greatest place. How do you reassess your marketing mix, I guess, for next year? And then the other question is on the programming side, any idea kind of on the number of hours of new original programming in '09, '08 and then what you're planning for '10?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian this is John, I'll take that. Listen, last year, we had a very successfully year, obviously, in terms of ratings and we had, indeed, lessened our marketing spend. But to be clear, the ability to continue that year after year would really be im
componenttext: Sure, Brian this is John, I'll take that. Listen, last year, we had a very successfully year, obviously, in terms of ratings and we had, indeed, lessened our marketing spend. But to be clear, the ability to continue that year after year would really be impossible. And with the momentum we had going in the '09, what we were able to do is take our existing audiences and by using the cross promotion of our networks, able to convince audiences to watch us more often or longer when they did tune in as a manner of improving our ratings. But for the long haul, there's no possible way that you can grow your audience without attracting new viewers along the way. And there's really no way to do that without marketing off your channels on other media platforms. And so, yes, it may seem like a question mark in your mind. I suppose that if you can raise ratings in a year without marketing, why not just quit marketing all together? But, of course, that would be not only a failure in terms of strategy, it would just invite competition in to steal the great momentum we've already created. In terms of hours of programming, Lori do you want to...

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Overall, that hasn't changed dramatically year-over-year, and we're not anticipating a huge change next year. So the hours are pretty standard. I think, over time, we've learned there's a certain amount of new program we have to introduce and we've l
componenttext: Yes. Overall, that hasn't changed dramatically year-over-year, and we're not anticipating a huge change next year. So the hours are pretty standard. I think, over time, we've learned there's a certain amount of new program we have to introduce and we've learned kind of what that level is. Even with Fine Living and the Cooking Channel swap, there's not a big impact as far as the number of hours on a [indiscernible].

componenttext: When we had our big tent pole event, like Next Food Network Star or HGTV Design Star, those events, we put some limited marketing against those and then strategically, we placed new series launches on the back end of those tent pole event. And so our marketing teams at HGTV and Food just did a great job using a limited amount of resources to create a great deal of momentum going into this year.

componenttext: When you think about the business, longer term and you adjust out a number of these one-time factors that we're all having to figure out how to model, do you inherently believe that the Lifestyle Media business should be able to show margin growth kind of year-in, year-out and do you try to model the business that way?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Jason this is Ken, I'll just take -- I think Joe, sort of more or less answered that question earlier. We've always been very proud of our margins. And I think it's based, as we've said many times, on the cost effectiveness of programming when you have ta
componenttext: Jason this is Ken, I'll just take -- I think Joe, sort of more or less answered that question earlier. We've always been very proud of our margins. And I think it's based, as we've said many times, on the cost effectiveness of programming when you have targeted networks like we have. But I think the best way to answer that is, as Joe said, we don't manage the margins, we manage not only the profitability but continue to grow, and the best evidence is in fifteenth year of this company. We had the strongest years with our cable networks that we've ever had in not only audience growth, but continuing to expand on other platforms or starting to move international. So long term, yes, we're going to continue to have very healthy margins but never at the expense of growing the businesses and growing these brands.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, the Travel Channel renewals are spread out beginning at the end of this year and then mostly 2012 to 2014. And we do believe that there is headroom to improve the affiliate fees for Travel Channel. The network, prior to us acquiring it, has don
componenttext: Yes, sure, the Travel Channel renewals are spread out beginning at the end of this year and then mostly 2012 to 2014. And we do believe that there is headroom to improve the affiliate fees for Travel Channel. The network, prior to us acquiring it, has done a fantastic job in developing a great ratings story. It's our intention to provide the support and resources to help them continue to do that. And as we saw with Food, to the extent that we can deliver a strong audience proposition, then the negotiations become that much easier to complete.

componenttextpreview: Jessica this is Joe. It's fair to assume that they're in the single digits. I think low might be a stretch there. They are pretty healthy going forward. But there, like I said, the bulk of it came in the first. It's not like a inflation escalator, it's re
componenttext: Jessica this is Joe. It's fair to assume that they're in the single digits. I think low might be a stretch there. They are pretty healthy going forward. But there, like I said, the bulk of it came in the first. It's not like a inflation escalator, it's real money going forward. But my explanation was sort of relative to HG where we got double-digit increases for three years in a row and then it sort of flatlined to an inflation-adjusted number, essentially. This is a big step up, upfront. But then, still meaningful going forward, higher than the HG.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: We've heard from other cable networks talking about tightening CPMs to broadcast. Could you tell us what you're seeing or I guess thinking about it more broadly, you think that your non-fiction networks are really substitutes for broadcast?
componenttext: We've heard from other cable networks talking about tightening CPMs to broadcast. Could you tell us what you're seeing or I guess thinking about it more broadly, you think that your non-fiction networks are really substitutes for broadcast?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, we've always felt like we're more than a substitute. We're a great alternative to broadcast because what we really do well is create a passionate audience around these categories, Home and Food and now Travel. And then we're able to monetize th
componenttext: Well, yes, we've always felt like we're more than a substitute. We're a great alternative to broadcast because what we really do well is create a passionate audience around these categories, Home and Food and now Travel. And then we're able to monetize that passion through our higher engagement and those results flow through our advertising rates and our affiliate fees and now our other platforms that we develop. And so it's really a different model for us. We're not out to attract an audience that is a mile wide and an inch deep. Our audience is richly associated with our brands and as a result, we monetize that relationship on TV and on all other platforms in a way that broadcast television could never dream of.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: Have you seen that CPM gap, which I assume is still there, between your networks and broadcast? Are you seeing that there over time?
componenttext: Have you seen that CPM gap, which I assume is still there, between your networks and broadcast? Are you seeing that there over time?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: The CPM gap is narrowing over time, absolutely. Just because of the reach premium that broadcast television has always enjoyed is being eroded year after year because of other cable networks, as well as ours, particularly cable networks that are more in c
componenttext: The CPM gap is narrowing over time, absolutely. Just because of the reach premium that broadcast television has always enjoyed is being eroded year after year because of other cable networks, as well as ours, particularly cable networks that are more in competition for a broad audience unlike us.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: We've heard other media managements talk about new platforms such as the iPad. We have also heard them say that they're interested in new distributors and new affiliates, but not necessarily new devices. Could just talk a little bit about your approach to
componenttext: We've heard other media managements talk about new platforms such as the iPad. We have also heard them say that they're interested in new distributors and new affiliates, but not necessarily new devices. Could just talk a little bit about your approach to these devices such as the iPad?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-10-2010
componenttextpreview: I know it's the buzz right now and every quarter or every year there's a new technology buzz, but we really think more about our consumers and how they're interacting with all this technology than the technology itself. We're fairly agnostic as to whether
componenttext: I know it's the buzz right now and every quarter or every year there's a new technology buzz, but we really think more about our consumers and how they're interacting with all this technology than the technology itself. We're fairly agnostic as to whether our consumers find and interact with our brands through an iPad or an iTouch or television screen or a magazine. Our passion is about finding our consumers and linking with them and their lives and being part of the solution for them in the Home, Food and Travel categories. And as long as we stay focused on consumer behavior, I think we'll find our way through the complexities of which platform, in which technology will win the day.
