componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the First Quarter Earnings Report Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Mark Kroeger. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Abraham, and good morning, all, and thanks for joining us. We'll start the conference call today with comments from Ken Lowe, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Joe NeCastro, our Chief Financial Officer. Our prepared remarks should take about
componenttext:
Thank you, Abraham, and good morning, all, and thanks for joining us. We'll start the conference call today with comments from Ken Lowe, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Joe NeCastro, our Chief Financial Officer. Our prepared remarks should take about 15 minutes then we'll open it up for questions. Also on the call are John Lansing, President of the Scripps Networks Operating Division; and Lori Hickok, Executive Vice President of Finance.
Let me remind you, if you prefer to listen in via the Internet, go to our website, click on Investor Relations and find the microphone icon on the landing page. An audio archive will be available on the site later today, and we'll leave it there for a week or so, so you can access it at your convenience.
Let me remind you that our discussion this morning will contain certain forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from those projected and some of the factors that may cause results to differ are set forth in our publicly filed documents, including our Form 10-K. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Ken.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone, and as always, thank you for your interest in Scripps Networks Interactive. Our first quarter was an exceptionally good one for the company and the shareholders. Allow me to share a few headlines with you.
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone, and as always, thank you for your interest in Scripps Networks Interactive. Our first quarter was an exceptionally good one for the company and the shareholders. Allow me to share a few headlines with you. 
Industry-leading growth in advertising sales, dramatically higher affiliate fee revenue, audience growth at all our flagship networks, the successful integration of the Travel Channel and lots of progress towards the upcoming debut of our brand-new Cooking Channel. Put it all together, and you have one of America's top-performing media companies and the clear leader in lifestyle television programming. 
The resounding popularity of our networks is evident in our exceptionally strong financial results. On a consolidated basis, total revenue for the company was up 32% during the quarter, driven by the addition of Travel, the steadily improving marketplace for advertising and substantially higher affiliate fees for our core brands, particularly Food Network and HGTV.
On an apples-to-apples basis, back in our Travel Channel results, total revenue for the quarter was up 20%. Now we're effectively monetizing the audience gains that we've achieved at Food Network and HGTV, benefiting from both the healthy rebound in advertising and the success we have last year negotiating new and improved affiliate fee agreements with our distribution partners.
Viewership growth continued at all three of our fully distributed networks, despite some serious competition from the Olympics, the NCAA basketball tournament and seasonally strong network programming. At Food Network, entertaining series and new specials like Worst Cooks in America help drive total household viewership, up 10% during primetime and 9% total day. And that was on top of strong total double-digit audience growth in the prior-year period. At HGTV, Holmes on Homes has been our breakout hit of the year as a growing number of viewers identify what home improvement perfectionist Mike Holmes with his very gritty disdain for shoddy workmanship. The result, the primetime audience at HGTV grew 9% during the quarter, and total day viewership jumped 11%. And many of these new viewers, by the way -- these are new viewers, by the way, thanks to some creative and effective marketing that we've done to promote the Holmes on Homes franchise.
Audience trends at Travel Channel are all moving in the right direction as well. Travel marked its sixth consecutive quarter of viewership growth, both in primetime and total day. In fact, the first quarter of 2010 was the best three month of ratings period in the network's history. Hit shows like Adam Richman's Man v. Food are gaining new and younger fans every day. Our integration of Travel, by the way, is nearly complete. We named the industry veteran, Laureen Ong, as the network's new President. And Laureen's probably best known for guiding the launch and development of Nat Geo. She is a true pro. And she'll be helping us build on Travel's strength as the go-to lifestyle brand.
We also assumed the advertising sales responsibilities March 29, and we're fully marketing the brand in the broadcast upfront, which is doing very well. And there's more to come. 
We're also on track for the Memorial Day debut of the brand-new Cooking Channel. We'll be launching the network with a good mix of new and familiar personalities who will take food enthusiasts deeper into the genre. Rachael Ray, Emeril Lagasse and Bobby Flay, all with original new series produced just for the Cooking Channel, will be joined by promising new personalities hosting shows like Chinese Food Made Easy, Everyday Exotic and French Food at Home.
Our plan at Cooking is to hit the ground running with a very strong 24/7 network that can take full advantage of the growing television food genre. Now based on the favorable response that we're getting from advertisers ahead of the launch, I'd say we're definitely headed in the right direction with the Cooking Channel. 
And don't forget about the DIY Network, our growing flanker brand in the Home category. First quarter viewership at DIY was up 13% total day, 8% in primetime and 10% on weekends, which is really the real primetime for do-it-yourself enthusiasts. The size of DIY's audience surged forward in 2009, given this more inventory for sale in last year's upfront. That, combined with the strength of the current scatter market, is why total revenue at DIY was up a very solid 22% during the quarter. We also added 2 million subs [subscribers] since the first quarter last year, making DIY one of America's fastest growing networks. We also launched the high-definition feed of DIY Network on May 1. 
Moving on to our branded websites. The improving ad trends are definitely evident. Revenue at our Digital businesses, led by www.foodnetwork.com and www.hgtv.com, was up 15% during the first quarter. Collectively, Scripps' websites are the clear leaders in their respective categories based on the amount of user traffic that they generate.
Internationally, we continue to build momentum with new launches and expanding distribution of our networks in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. Food Network's viewership in the U.K. continue to grow during the quarter, and we launched an international version of Fine Living Network across 60 countries in the EMEA region. As you probably saw earlier this week, we ended discussions with a potential partner in India, after we were unable to work out specifics of the transaction that we announced back in November. Our interest in entering the India market is by no means diminished, and we'll be exploring other alternatives as part of our overall international expansion strategy.
And finally, at our Online Comparison Shopping businesses, we're delivering a better user experience for our consumers and customers in a more effective marketing platform for our merchant partners. Direct leads to online merchants from our websites grew 11% during the quarter, a sure indication that shoppers and retailers are getting more value by turning to BizRate, Shopzilla and Beso. We look for Shopzilla's financial performance to start turning more positive in the back half of the year. 
As 2010 progresses, we'll remain focused on our strategic priorities, which include fully integrating the Travel Channel and building on the network's strength as a destination brand. We capitalize in on the growing interest in Food as a popular television genre with the launch, May 31, of the Cooking Channel. Internationally, we're looking for opportunities to explore our lifestyle networks and programming expertise throughout the EMEA, Asia, India and Latin America. And last but not least, we'll focus on building brand awareness and growing audiences at all of our networks. All in all, given the strength of our first quarter results, I'd say we're off to a very good start for this year. 
With that, now let me turn it over to Joe. Joe?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ken. Good morning, everyone. I'm sure most of you have had time to review the press release we issued this morning, so I won't repeat it here. Other than to note, as Ken did, that we had an exceptionally strong start to the year. Underlying our po
componenttext:
Thanks, Ken. Good morning, everyone. I'm sure most of you have had time to review the press release we issued this morning, so I won't repeat it here. Other than to note, as Ken did, that we had an exceptionally strong start to the year. Underlying our positive results are the improving ad market and the success we had last year, renewing distribution agreements at considerably more attractive rates, particularly for Food Network. 
A strong audience growth at most of our networks in 2009 also gave us more impressions to sell in last year's upfront and put us in an excellent position to benefit from the strengthening scatter marketplace. Remember, given the weaker upfront pricing environment a year ago, we held some inventory back for scatter. Sequential improvement in scatter pricing continue through the first three months of the year. And for the second quarter, it's trending up about 20% to 25% above last year's upfront. Scatter versus scatter pricing is up mid-teens compared with last year.
Given the health of the marketplace, we expect double-digit advertising growth to continue in the second quarter. And as you'd expect, the current strength in scatter bodes well for this year's upfront, which will have its most immediate impact during the fourth quarter of the year. It's important to remember though that ad revenue comparisons get increasingly more difficult for us in the back half of the year.
As for affiliate revenues, the first quarter came in pretty much as we had anticipated, with an organic growth rate of about 40%, thanks largely to our new rate card. We're holding firm on our expectations for affiliate revenue growth for the full year as we noted in the press release.
On the cost side, we've called out one-time expenses that were incurred during the quarter to support our affiliate renewals and our integration of the Travel Channel. The affiliate marketing and legal expenses of $11 million are all now behind us, since those activities occurred largely in January. And a large percentage of the Travel transition costs were also incurred during the first quarter.
We're now expecting Travel transition costs for the full year to end up near the lower end of the $30 million to $40 million range that we've provided in March. Much of the remaining Travel transition costs will be incurred in the second quarter. And as a result, we've lowered the full year range for non-programming expenses from our previous guidance.
Total operating expenses at our Lifestyle Media segment were up 47% during the quarter, and much of this increase is due to the addition of the Travel Channel and these one-time items. But as planned, we've also taken advantage of our very strong ad and affiliate revenue growth to restore some of our marketing budgets. You'll remember that we spent considerably less money on marketing during the first quarter last year because of the recession, which, of course, makes the increase in spending this year appear a bit outsized. 
Some timing issues also had an impact. We launched targeted marketing campaigns during the first quarter to promote the Worst Cooks special event at Food Network and the popular Holmes on Homes series at HGTV. The results were right on target. Worst Cooks in America performed superbly for us, averaging 1.0 rating among adults 25 to 54. We also improved the audience delivery for its timeslot by 51% over the prior year.
Holmes on Homes, meanwhile, has become one of HGTV's breakout hit for the year. During the height of the marketing campaign, which ended in March, the show's audience was up about 30% compared with the prior four-week period. This marketing money was well spent, we believe.
Turning to other items, let me add a little color on our capital spending. We're putting the finishing touches on a facility expansion in Knoxville. And we included the CapEx related to the Travel integration in our full year guidance. Our apologies, by the way. There was a typo in the release. The non-recurring cost for our operating facility expansion for the year will be about $35 million, not $9 million as it's stated in the release. Once these items go away, we're expecting a normalized CapEx run rate of $50 million to $60 million starting in 2011.
And finally, one balance sheet item. We finished the first quarter with about $320 million in cash. Our plan for now is to maintain a strong cash position and the flexibility that it will afford us to act on opportunities in the marketplace and to meet our future obligations. 
With that, operator, we're ready to take questions.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: First, guys, can you give us an update on the international strategy meaning, does the end to the NDTV deal have you considering more of a build and partner strategy versus more of a partner strategy?
componenttext: First, guys, can you give us an update on the international strategy meaning, does the end to the NDTV deal have you considering more of a build and partner strategy versus more of a partner strategy?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Joe, John. That's a good question. No, it does not really signal a change in our strategy. We're being opportunistic wherever we can. I think our view is that we would like to take an ownership position and even a control position wherever we can.
componenttext: This is Joe, John. That's a good question. No, it does not really signal a change in our strategy. We're being opportunistic wherever we can. I think our view is that we would like to take an ownership position and even a control position wherever we can. We do still strongly believe that we will need partners locally in all these markets, especially a market like India. So it doesn't -- the change in NDTV had more to do with that specifics of that deal than it did any kind of change in strategy.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And separately, with the dispute related to the affiliates, are renewal negotiations behind you? I assume that loyalty to your brands from consumers became pretty evident to you guys. And so as you think about future food renegotiations, does that allow y
componenttext: And separately, with the dispute related to the affiliates, are renewal negotiations behind you? I assume that loyalty to your brands from consumers became pretty evident to you guys. And so as you think about future food renegotiations, does that allow you to be maybe more aggressive knowing that consumers appear to be willing to switch providers? Or maybe has the bar been set meaning, you have something like maybe 90% conviction? And what do you expect in terms of the monthly fee, given the recent deals?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, this is John. Good morning. Well, we certainly were gratified to see the loyalty to our brand, especially the Food Network brand. And to say that, that gratification would translate into more confidence going into future negotiations, I think t
componenttext: Yes, John, this is John. Good morning. Well, we certainly were gratified to see the loyalty to our brand, especially the Food Network brand. And to say that, that gratification would translate into more confidence going into future negotiations, I think that's a fair assumption, yes.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Karimzad of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Karimzad of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, an HGTV question and a bit on Travel. Over at HG, you did well in the first quarter on the ratings side. But it looks like on the schedule, you've increased the House Hunters' presence quite a bit. If you could give us some color on what w
componenttext: I guess, first, an HGTV question and a bit on Travel. Over at HG, you did well in the first quarter on the ratings side. But it looks like on the schedule, you've increased the House Hunters' presence quite a bit. If you could give us some color on what was the reasoning behind that because it is one of your higher viewership shows. And then on the Travel side, ad revenue backing in. It looks like it did nicely maybe kind of high single, low doubles there, but not quite as well as say, Food even though both of them had very good audience growth in '09 into first quarter '10. Can you give us a sense of maybe as you transition the sales force to your side, are there some low-hanging fruit there that they weren't tapping?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. House Hunters has been a perennial success story, breakout hit for HGTV. It has for over 10 years and continues to do so. Of course, we've expanded the genre now to include House Hunters International. And the positioning of it on the schedul
componenttext: Sure, Brian. House Hunters has been a perennial success story, breakout hit for HGTV. It has for over 10 years and continues to do so. Of course, we've expanded the genre now to include House Hunters International. And the positioning of it on the schedule allows us to put new series on the back end of it to introduce the audience to those series. And so what we're seeing is the success of new series such as Holmes on Homes and Selling New York. And even our First-Time Home Buyers' block have all benefited from the boost of audience that House Hunters creates. So think of House Hunters as really a catalyst on our schedule, creating an opportunity for us to create and grow new franchises. And the team at HGTV has done a terrific job over the last years and making that really pay off for them, particularly with Holmes on Homes, which saw a 30% growth year-over-year in the time period in the first quarter with the introduction of the new season. In terms of Travel, we took over the ad sales, as we said earlier, at the end of March. And I guess the way we think about it is in our portfolio, Travel Channel is one of our three crown jewels. It will get all of the attention, if not even a little more attention, since it's a bit of a start-up for us as a Food Network or an HGTV. It's not anything short of a top priority for us. We promoted one of our young stars in the Ad Sales department, Greg Regis, to manage the Ad Sales group. We made some terrific hires for the Ad Sales team. We've effectively created an entire Ad Sales team dedicated to the success of Travel Channel. And I can tell you this, in the first quarter, prior to us taking it over, the DR [depositary receipt] component of Travel Channel was upwards of 30% and the DR component of Travel under this, our Ad Sales team will be something closer to the mid-single digits as we're pushing much, much more aggressively in the scatter. And we'll be pushing more aggressively in the upfront marketplace.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Alexia Quadrani of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Alexia Quadrani of JPMorgan.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned, I think, in your prepared comments that the scatter was up mid-teens over scatter in the second quarter. Can you tell us how that compares to the average scatter pricing during the first quarter? And I guess any further thoughts you may hav
componenttext: You mentioned, I think, in your prepared comments that the scatter was up mid-teens over scatter in the second quarter. Can you tell us how that compares to the average scatter pricing during the first quarter? And I guess any further thoughts you may have on how the upfront may turn out this year.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Alexia. We are seeing an improving scatter marketplace each month of the year. And on the second quarter, as you noted, we're seeing mid-teens, I should say, growth in scatter pricing. That's up of high single digit CPM growth in the first quarter.
componenttext: Sure, Alexia. We are seeing an improving scatter marketplace each month of the year. And on the second quarter, as you noted, we're seeing mid-teens, I should say, growth in scatter pricing. That's up of high single digit CPM growth in the first quarter. So it's doubled in terms of year-over-year growth. In terms of our scatter pricing to last year's upfront, it's moved now in the second quarter to 25% on top of last year's upfront marketplace. And that is continuing to improve week-to-week. So barring something unforeseen, we anticipate there being a significant improvement in the upfront marketplace, simply because the advertisers are paying such a premium right now to get into the scatter marketplace. And we believe that will translate into volume growth for the cable industry in the upfront upwards of 20%. And in terms of Scripps Networks, I would anticipate our CPM growth in the upcoming upfront would be in the mid- to high singles, leaning towards the high singles.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And is there anyone vertical? Or is it really across the board, driving the strength in the scatter?
componenttext: And is there anyone vertical? Or is it really across the board, driving the strength in the scatter?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: For us, it's the same category that typically offer our strength. For us, the Food category is the number one category across all of our networks, consumer products, retail, financial and automotive. Probably the most interesting growth story year-over-ye
componenttext: For us, it's the same category that typically offer our strength. For us, the Food category is the number one category across all of our networks, consumer products, retail, financial and automotive. Probably the most interesting growth story year-over-year is automotive.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And would you say travel has a lot of overlap in terms of the client base?
componenttext: And would you say travel has a lot of overlap in terms of the client base?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're beginning to develop that, some of that overlap, if you will. There was such a reliance on DR in the past, and now we're able to introduce Travel to a variety of our other clients. And as we work with Laureen Ong to improve the female composit
componenttext: Well, we're beginning to develop that, some of that overlap, if you will. There was such a reliance on DR in the past, and now we're able to introduce Travel to a variety of our other clients. And as we work with Laureen Ong to improve the female composition of that network then we anticipate moving more aggressively into the consumer product goods that today are not all that well represented on the network.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And last question on the Cooking Channel, where do you think distribution can go ultimately there?
componenttext: And last question on the Cooking Channel, where do you think distribution can go ultimately there?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, right now, Fine Living distribution is sitting at about $58 million, and I anticipate that we will step into that footprint pretty much, if not 100%, close to that.
componenttext: Well, right now, Fine Living distribution is sitting at about $58 million, and I anticipate that we will step into that footprint pretty much, if not 100%, close to that.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Helfstein of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Helfstein of Oppenheimer.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: So just thinking about the strength of the advertising, which is the best in the industry right now, I mean, how much of this do you think is a recognition of the effectiveness of advertising on your networks versus your ratings strength versus an improve
componenttext: So just thinking about the strength of the advertising, which is the best in the industry right now, I mean, how much of this do you think is a recognition of the effectiveness of advertising on your networks versus your ratings strength versus an improved pricing environment? And then just secondly, if we think about the international opportunity longer term, Discovery gets about a third of their revenue internationally, granted they've been at it internationally for a long time. What do you think the right long-term goal is for international as a percent of Lifestyle Media revenues?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start, and then I'll let Joe grab the international question. Great question on our ad growth. We're certainly very proud of our Ad Sales team to deliver 14% growth. And you make a very good point. For many, many years now, we've been talking a
componenttext: Well, I'll start, and then I'll let Joe grab the international question. Great question on our ad growth. We're certainly very proud of our Ad Sales team to deliver 14% growth. And you make a very good point. For many, many years now, we've been talking about the method that Scripps Networks approaches the ad marketplace, which is really selling the engagement that our audiences have with our programming and how commercials that run within our programming tend to work very, very well for advertisers. Because in many cases, our audiences look at the advertising as part of the programming. It helps complete the cycle, if you will, of the inspiration the programming creates. And then the advertising provides a place for an audience to make good on that inspiration. But also going along with that, we invested somewhat in programming and marketing this year as was noted in our earlier prepared remarks. And we also pushed forward our advertising guarantees, our ratings guarantees. We bet on the upside based on that investment in programming and marketing. And thankfully, the ratings came in and met those higher and more aggressive ratings guarantees. And as a result, higher ratings meeting a stronger marketplace and then being able to monetize the engagement of our audience really served us well in this quarter.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on international?
componenttext: And then on international?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason, this is Joe. On international, we certainly look at Discovery and Viacom and others in terms of the composition of their revenue and how much is international. We certainly think of them as great benchmarks. But frankly, we'd be happy with hal
componenttext: Yes, Jason, this is Joe. On international, we certainly look at Discovery and Viacom and others in terms of the composition of their revenue and how much is international. We certainly think of them as great benchmarks. But frankly, we'd be happy with half of what they get. We don't have a pre-established goal for this. I think there are great opportunities for our programming. And we've been very warmly received around the globe. But these are deals you do one at a time. We're more interested in making a very good return on the investment than we are in the absolute size of the business at this point. But that said, we think there's plenty of room to run. And as our plans develop and as we execute on some of these opportunities, we'll probably get a little more definitive about where we think it will ultimately go.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente of Barclays Capital.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: First question for Joe, just on the guidance on international. Now expected an operating loss for international of $11 million to $16 million. What was the prior expectation on that? And I apologize if you said that.
componenttext: First question for Joe, just on the guidance on international. Now expected an operating loss for international of $11 million to $16 million. What was the prior expectation on that? And I apologize if you said that.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we had said we were expecting to lose up to $20 million on international. $15 million to $20 million was the range we used.
componenttext: Yes, I think we had said we were expecting to lose up to $20 million on international. $15 million to $20 million was the range we used.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe this one for John. If you could just remind us your schedule for upcoming affiliate deals. I think that you might have a big operator that's scheduled to go on Food Network and then on HGTV. If you could just remind us, who's coming up? And
componenttext: And then maybe this one for John. If you could just remind us your schedule for upcoming affiliate deals. I think that you might have a big operator that's scheduled to go on Food Network and then on HGTV. If you could just remind us, who's coming up? And then as part of that, is it safe for us to assume that terms for any new affiliate deals will mirror terms that you've already received from other operators that you have obviously negotiated with at the end of '09 as of January 1?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Anthony, without getting into any detail on the affiliate agreements, of course, the terms are confidential, including the term of the contracts themselves. But we have no significant activity this year beyond a single operator related to Travel. And
componenttext: Yes, Anthony, without getting into any detail on the affiliate agreements, of course, the terms are confidential, including the term of the contracts themselves. But we have no significant activity this year beyond a single operator related to Travel. And then after that, we don't expect any major activity around Food for a couple of years and around HGTV for three years.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Mitchelson of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Mitchelson of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: I know it's the sort of after the fact and you indicated this coming into the first quarter. But the $11 million or so on spending against the affiliate renewals, I mean, really the dispute was just with Cablevision now. They've only got 3 million subs. A
componenttext: I know it's the sort of after the fact and you indicated this coming into the first quarter. But the $11 million or so on spending against the affiliate renewals, I mean, really the dispute was just with Cablevision now. They've only got 3 million subs. And so I guess the first question is, is the $11 million just against Cablevision? Because that seems like a lot of money relative to the revenue that you get from them.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll answer that, and then I'll let John add some color. Indeed, it was related to that one dispute. But that's a very valuable market. And advertising is not always cheap, especially in New York markets. So John, you have any color you want to add?
componenttext: Well, I'll answer that, and then I'll let John add some color. Indeed, it was related to that one dispute. But that's a very valuable market. And advertising is not always cheap, especially in New York markets. So John, you have any color you want to add?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: It's true, and you also have to consider that we really had no choice but to bring in the rate with Cablevision at the same level on our rate card as we have with others because due to MFN considerations, we had to protect the rate cards. So the spending
componenttext: It's true, and you also have to consider that we really had no choice but to bring in the rate with Cablevision at the same level on our rate card as we have with others because due to MFN considerations, we had to protect the rate cards. So the spending against Cablevision had a multiplying effect were we not successful, and we were successful. So the spending made sense.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the Travel transition expenses, I mean, typically, when we see acquisitions either there's restructuring charges or things are capitalized. And in your case, you're running [ph] (1:04:45) these expenses through. I mean, can you just give us a
componenttext: And then on the Travel transition expenses, I mean, typically, when we see acquisitions either there's restructuring charges or things are capitalized. And in your case, you're running [ph] (1:04:45) these expenses through. I mean, can you just give us a sense of what the spending is? I mean, it's a pretty large dollar amount, but obviously it's a big deal.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, and I can assure you we're following all the rules we could follow. We are probably a little more conservative than some companies. You don't have as much room to capitalize costs in a transition. A lot of these are related to job terminations and s
componenttext: Well, and I can assure you we're following all the rules we could follow. We are probably a little more conservative than some companies. You don't have as much room to capitalize costs in a transition. A lot of these are related to job terminations and some contract breakage. There was the agreements that they'd executed with Discovery. There are charges related to transitioning those away from Discovery. So it's a number of things that we didn't think had a future benefit to us. So we ran them through.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm just curious. I mean, you're being very transparent with the numbers, so it's easy for us to add them back for future years. So that's been helpful. And just for the affiliate revenues, now that we have a first quarter run rate, I mean, I guess
componenttext: Well, I'm just curious. I mean, you're being very transparent with the numbers, so it's easy for us to add them back for future years. So that's been helpful. And just for the affiliate revenues, now that we have a first quarter run rate, I mean, I guess the guidance implies that stays relatively flattish going forward, is that right? Is that how we should think about it the rest of the year?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly upfront strategy. I mean, you talked about high single digit CPMs, is this an upfront where at that price you're taking as much volume as you can even though -- I mean, scatter pricing right now is awfully healthy. And so I guess a lo
componenttext: And then just lastly upfront strategy. I mean, you talked about high single digit CPMs, is this an upfront where at that price you're taking as much volume as you can even though -- I mean, scatter pricing right now is awfully healthy. And so I guess a lot of us starts to get worried what the world looks like a year from now. Can we maintain this level of scatter pricing a year from now? Do you manage your upfront sellout and restrain it so that you have enough inventory to take advantage of scattering next year? Or do you have enough DR and other things out there that you just go for volume in the upfront? So any comments on that would be helpful.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a little bit early there to make that call, to be honest with you. But as the scatter goes, the pendulum begins swinging towards the upfront in terms of activity. Typically, we're looking at somewhere in the range of 45% to 50% that we put in
componenttext: I think it's a little bit early there to make that call, to be honest with you. But as the scatter goes, the pendulum begins swinging towards the upfront in terms of activity. Typically, we're looking at somewhere in the range of 45% to 50% that we put into an upfront, and that will be our starting point. And then based on the pricing increases that we can achieve, based on the condition of the scatter market at that time, we'll make a call as to where we'll end up. But I wouldn't anticipate us making a bit [ph] (1:06:49) off of a percentage of inventory within a range of 4% to 5%.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Eric Handler of MKM Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Eric Handler of MKM Partners.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to the Travel Channel transition and the catalyst that you see there coming up over the next year, where are you in terms of your investments and programming? And at what point do we start seeing a slate that reflects those investments?
componenttext: With regard to the Travel Channel transition and the catalyst that you see there coming up over the next year, where are you in terms of your investments and programming? And at what point do we start seeing a slate that reflects those investments?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the good news is that we hired one of the best in the business, and Laureen Ong to come in and work with the team and create the vision for growth. So it's more than just, in our minds, a programming slate per se as it is a concept to be developed a
componenttext: Well, the good news is that we hired one of the best in the business, and Laureen Ong to come in and work with the team and create the vision for growth. So it's more than just, in our minds, a programming slate per se as it is a concept to be developed around a Travel programming and branding initiative that will require that we have two to three, perhaps four to five series that become very, very well known and become definitive for creating the brand and creates a destination point much like Food Network and HGTV have become and DIY. And so the slate that we're running through right now was the development from last year. So the most recent series, including Food Wars is now -- those are now the last of the 2010 slate coming out of '09. And now, we have a significant programming budget of $50 million put against the development of a new slate. We have Laureen and her team and a chance to really think through how to do that. And perhaps most importantly, we have the expertise of our programming geniuses at the Food Network and HGTV and others, who will work together with Travel and see what learnings we can develop from our other success stories. So that in creating the Travel brand that will be manifested through programming success stories. We don't have to relearn some of the techniques that we've picked up along the way.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Would you say then September might be too early to start seeing a transitioning slate and it's more of  a 2011 situation there? Or can we start seeing things by the fall?
componenttext: Would you say then September might be too early to start seeing a transitioning slate and it's more of  a 2011 situation there? Or can we start seeing things by the fall?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you'll start to see some things by the fall. But I think the majority of it would be first quarter 2011.
componenttext: I think you'll start to see some things by the fall. But I think the majority of it would be first quarter 2011.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Harrigan of Wunderlich Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Harrigan of Wunderlich Securities.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about what you're doing on a skunkworks basis on the interactive advertising side with EBIT and all that, given how committed your users are to some of the linear channel side. It seems like that might get even further amplified with interact
componenttext: Can you talk about what you're doing on a skunkworks basis on the interactive advertising side with EBIT and all that, given how committed your users are to some of the linear channel side. It seems like that might get even further amplified with interactive. And then could you talk more about what you're doing to allow people more mobile access to your programming, given that various priorities that come into play there?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, ironically, one of our biggest initiatives along the lines of interactive advertising is with our partner, Cablevision, who after we were beyond the dispute from earlier this year, we partnered with Cablevision on an experimental platform through a
componenttext: Well, ironically, one of our biggest initiatives along the lines of interactive advertising is with our partner, Cablevision, who after we were beyond the dispute from earlier this year, we partnered with Cablevision on an experimental platform through a third-party vendor called ActiveVideo on a new interactive advertising platform. And it looks very promising. I just had an update on it earlier this week, very interesting indeed. We also have a distribution deal with a website called www.5min.com. It's m-i-n as in minute. www.5min.com where they are now distributing videos from all of our channels, and then we're selling that distributed network around the world. And we're seeing an amazing uptick in pushing our videos out in this distributed model, so that we're seeing ad revenue against videos that rivals the revenue on our own website through www.5min.com. And then in terms of mobile, our friends at Travel were in many ways further along than we were in thinking about mobile. And so we're really working closely with them in developing a mobile expertise. Food Network -- and both HGTV and Food Network have developed some interesting applications for iPhone and iPad. And we'll work together between our application development and the mobile expertise of Travel to see what opportunity we can create.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: It's actually Micah on for Ben. Just a couple of quick questions. On the international investment, the dilution guidance for this year, Joe, I don't know if you have any color on next year. What would you be expecting for that dilution, whether that gets
componenttext: It's actually Micah on for Ben. Just a couple of quick questions. On the international investment, the dilution guidance for this year, Joe, I don't know if you have any color on next year. What would you be expecting for that dilution, whether that gets better or worse in 2011?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, we really don't have any guidance to give on that at this moment. Frankly, it's too early. What we're going to be working on is the Asian strategy now that we've made the change. So I think it's a work in progress. It's too early to really give
componenttext: Actually, we really don't have any guidance to give on that at this moment. Frankly, it's too early. What we're going to be working on is the Asian strategy now that we've made the change. So I think it's a work in progress. It's too early to really give any guidance on that.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the uses of free cash this year, I know that the NDTV JV wasn't expected to be a big use of cash in terms of investing. Could you just update a little bit with regard to your priorities on deploying free cash flow versus programming expense an
componenttext: And then on the uses of free cash this year, I know that the NDTV JV wasn't expected to be a big use of cash in terms of investing. Could you just update a little bit with regard to your priorities on deploying free cash flow versus programming expense and how you're looking at the balance sheet right now?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think we mentioned in the opening comments that our view is that we're not going to do anything at this moment in terms of the cash balance that we have. We will maintain a certain amount in the business. Our priorities are as they've always been,
componenttext: Sure. I think we mentioned in the opening comments that our view is that we're not going to do anything at this moment in terms of the cash balance that we have. We will maintain a certain amount in the business. Our priorities are as they've always been, making sure that we have adequate programming on the one hand. But outside of the core of the business, we still have an interest in the Food Network stub and beyond that, international opportunities. I think they're probably the top two priorities. So that's how we think about it at this moment. We don't think we have enough of a cash balance to worry about having too much on hand.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And at this time, there are no further questions.
componenttext: And at this time, there are no further questions.

componenttext: Okay. Well, thank you, Abraham, and thank you, everybody. This is Mark. I'll be here for the rest of the day if you have any follow-ups. You can read the dial-back instructions.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the First Quarter Earnings Report Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Mark Kro
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the First Quarter Earnings Report Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Mark Kroeger. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Abraham, and good morning, all, and thanks for joining us. We'll start the conference call today with comments from Ken Lowe, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Joe NeCastro, our Chief Financial Officer. Our prepared remarks should take about
componenttext:
Thank you, Abraham, and good morning, all, and thanks for joining us. We'll start the conference call today with comments from Ken Lowe, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Joe NeCastro, our Chief Financial Officer. Our prepared remarks should take about 15 minutes then we'll open it up for questions. Also on the call are John Lansing, President of the Scripps Networks Operating Division; and Lori Hickok, Executive Vice President of Finance.
Let me remind you, if you prefer to listen in via the Internet, go to our website, click on Investor Relations and find the microphone icon on the landing page. An audio archive will be available on the site later today, and we'll leave it there for a week or so, so you can access it at your convenience.
Let me remind you that our discussion this morning will contain certain forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from those projected and some of the factors that may cause results to differ are set forth in our publicly filed documents, including our Form 10-K. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Ken.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone, and as always, thank you for your interest in Scripps Networks Interactive. Our first quarter was an exceptionally good one for the company and the shareholders. Allow me to share a few headlines with you.
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone, and as always, thank you for your interest in Scripps Networks Interactive. Our first quarter was an exceptionally good one for the company and the shareholders. Allow me to share a few headlines with you. 
Industry-leading growth in advertising sales, dramatically higher affiliate fee revenue, audience growth at all our flagship networks, the successful integration of the Travel Channel and lots of progress towards the upcoming debut of our brand-new Cooking Channel. Put it all together, and you have one of America's top-performing media companies and the clear leader in lifestyle television programming. 
The resounding popularity of our networks is evident in our exceptionally strong financial results. On a consolidated basis, total revenue for the company was up 32% during the quarter, driven by the addition of Travel, the steadily improving marketplace for advertising and substantially higher affiliate fees for our core brands, particularly Food Network and HGTV.
On an apples-to-apples basis, back in our Travel Channel results, total revenue for the quarter was up 20%. Now we're effectively monetizing the audience gains that we've achieved at Food Network and HGTV, benefiting from both the healthy rebound in advertising and the success we have last year negotiating new and improved affiliate fee agreements with our distribution partners.
Viewership growth continued at all three of our fully distributed networks, despite some serious competition from the Olympics, the NCAA basketball tournament and seasonally strong network programming. At Food Network, entertaining series and new specials like Worst Cooks in America help drive total household viewership, up 10% during primetime and 9% total day. And that was on top of strong total double-digit audience growth in the prior-year period. At HGTV, Holmes on Homes has been our breakout hit of the year as a growing number of viewers identify what home improvement perfectionist Mike Holmes with his very gritty disdain for shoddy workmanship. The result, the primetime audience at HGTV grew 9% during the quarter, and total day viewership jumped 11%. And many of these new viewers, by the way -- these are new viewers, by the way, thanks to some creative and effective marketing that we've done to promote the Holmes on Homes franchise.
Audience trends at Travel Channel are all moving in the right direction as well. Travel marked its sixth consecutive quarter of viewership growth, both in primetime and total day. In fact, the first quarter of 2010 was the best three month of ratings period in the network's history. Hit shows like Adam Richman's Man v. Food are gaining new and younger fans every day. Our integration of Travel, by the way, is nearly complete. We named the industry veteran, Laureen Ong, as the network's new President. And Laureen's probably best known for guiding the launch and development of Nat Geo. She is a true pro. And she'll be helping us build on Travel's strength as the go-to lifestyle brand.
We also assumed the advertising sales responsibilities March 29, and we're fully marketing the brand in the broadcast upfront, which is doing very well. And there's more to come. 
We're also on track for the Memorial Day debut of the brand-new Cooking Channel. We'll be launching the network with a good mix of new and familiar personalities who will take food enthusiasts deeper into the genre. Rachael Ray, Emeril Lagasse and Bobby Flay, all with original new series produced just for the Cooking Channel, will be joined by promising new personalities hosting shows like Chinese Food Made Easy, Everyday Exotic and French Food at Home.
Our plan at Cooking is to hit the ground running with a very strong 24/7 network that can take full advantage of the growing television food genre. Now based on the favorable response that we're getting from advertisers ahead of the launch, I'd say we're definitely headed in the right direction with the Cooking Channel. 
And don't forget about the DIY Network, our growing flanker brand in the Home category. First quarter viewership at DIY was up 13% total day, 8% in primetime and 10% on weekends, which is really the real primetime for do-it-yourself enthusiasts. The size of DIY's audience surged forward in 2009, given this more inventory for sale in last year's upfront. That, combined with the strength of the current scatter market, is why total revenue at DIY was up a very solid 22% during the quarter. We also added 2 million subs [subscribers] since the first quarter last year, making DIY one of America's fastest growing networks. We also launched the high-definition feed of DIY Network on May 1. 
Moving on to our branded websites. The improving ad trends are definitely evident. Revenue at our Digital businesses, led by www.foodnetwork.com and www.hgtv.com, was up 15% during the first quarter. Collectively, Scripps' websites are the clear leaders in their respective categories based on the amount of user traffic that they generate.
Internationally, we continue to build momentum with new launches and expanding distribution of our networks in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. Food Network's viewership in the U.K. continue to grow during the quarter, and we launched an international version of Fine Living Network across 60 countries in the EMEA region. As you probably saw earlier this week, we ended discussions with a potential partner in India, after we were unable to work out specifics of the transaction that we announced back in November. Our interest in entering the India market is by no means diminished, and we'll be exploring other alternatives as part of our overall international expansion strategy.
And finally, at our Online Comparison Shopping businesses, we're delivering a better user experience for our consumers and customers in a more effective marketing platform for our merchant partners. Direct leads to online merchants from our websites grew 11% during the quarter, a sure indication that shoppers and retailers are getting more value by turning to BizRate, Shopzilla and Beso. We look for Shopzilla's financial performance to start turning more positive in the back half of the year. 
As 2010 progresses, we'll remain focused on our strategic priorities, which include fully integrating the Travel Channel and building on the network's strength as a destination brand. We capitalize in on the growing interest in Food as a popular television genre with the launch, May 31, of the Cooking Channel. Internationally, we're looking for opportunities to explore our lifestyle networks and programming expertise throughout the EMEA, Asia, India and Latin America. And last but not least, we'll focus on building brand awareness and growing audiences at all of our networks. All in all, given the strength of our first quarter results, I'd say we're off to a very good start for this year. 
With that, now let me turn it over to Joe. Joe?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ken. Good morning, everyone. I'm sure most of you have had time to review the press release we issued this morning, so I won't repeat it here. Other than to note, as Ken did, that we had an exceptionally strong start to the year. Underlying our po
componenttext:
Thanks, Ken. Good morning, everyone. I'm sure most of you have had time to review the press release we issued this morning, so I won't repeat it here. Other than to note, as Ken did, that we had an exceptionally strong start to the year. Underlying our positive results are the improving ad market and the success we had last year, renewing distribution agreements at considerably more attractive rates, particularly for Food Network. 
A strong audience growth at most of our networks in 2009 also gave us more impressions to sell in last year's upfront and put us in an excellent position to benefit from the strengthening scatter marketplace. Remember, given the weaker upfront pricing environment a year ago, we held some inventory back for scatter. Sequential improvement in scatter pricing continue through the first three months of the year. And for the second quarter, it's trending up about 20% to 25% above last year's upfront. Scatter versus scatter pricing is up mid-teens compared with last year.
Given the health of the marketplace, we expect double-digit advertising growth to continue in the second quarter. And as you'd expect, the current strength in scatter bodes well for this year's upfront, which will have its most immediate impact during the fourth quarter of the year. It's important to remember though that ad revenue comparisons get increasingly more difficult for us in the back half of the year.
As for affiliate revenues, the first quarter came in pretty much as we had anticipated, with an organic growth rate of about 40%, thanks largely to our new rate card. We're holding firm on our expectations for affiliate revenue growth for the full year as we noted in the press release.
On the cost side, we've called out one-time expenses that were incurred during the quarter to support our affiliate renewals and our integration of the Travel Channel. The affiliate marketing and legal expenses of $11 million are all now behind us, since those activities occurred largely in January. And a large percentage of the Travel transition costs were also incurred during the first quarter.
We're now expecting Travel transition costs for the full year to end up near the lower end of the $30 million to $40 million range that we've provided in March. Much of the remaining Travel transition costs will be incurred in the second quarter. And as a result, we've lowered the full year range for non-programming expenses from our previous guidance.
Total operating expenses at our Lifestyle Media segment were up 47% during the quarter, and much of this increase is due to the addition of the Travel Channel and these one-time items. But as planned, we've also taken advantage of our very strong ad and affiliate revenue growth to restore some of our marketing budgets. You'll remember that we spent considerably less money on marketing during the first quarter last year because of the recession, which, of course, makes the increase in spending this year appear a bit outsized. 
Some timing issues also had an impact. We launched targeted marketing campaigns during the first quarter to promote the Worst Cooks special event at Food Network and the popular Holmes on Homes series at HGTV. The results were right on target. Worst Cooks in America performed superbly for us, averaging 1.0 rating among adults 25 to 54. We also improved the audience delivery for its timeslot by 51% over the prior year.
Holmes on Homes, meanwhile, has become one of HGTV's breakout hit for the year. During the height of the marketing campaign, which ended in March, the show's audience was up about 30% compared with the prior four-week period. This marketing money was well spent, we believe.
Turning to other items, let me add a little color on our capital spending. We're putting the finishing touches on a facility expansion in Knoxville. And we included the CapEx related to the Travel integration in our full year guidance. Our apologies, by the way. There was a typo in the release. The non-recurring cost for our operating facility expansion for the year will be about $35 million, not $9 million as it's stated in the release. Once these items go away, we're expecting a normalized CapEx run rate of $50 million to $60 million starting in 2011.
And finally, one balance sheet item. We finished the first quarter with about $320 million in cash. Our plan for now is to maintain a strong cash position and the flexibility that it will afford us to act on opportunities in the marketplace and to meet our future obligations. 
With that, operator, we're ready to take questions.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: First, guys, can you give us an update on the international strategy meaning, does the end to the NDTV deal have you considering more of a build and partner strategy versus more of a partner strategy?
componenttext: First, guys, can you give us an update on the international strategy meaning, does the end to the NDTV deal have you considering more of a build and partner strategy versus more of a partner strategy?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Joe, John. That's a good question. No, it does not really signal a change in our strategy. We're being opportunistic wherever we can. I think our view is that we would like to take an ownership position and even a control position wherever we can.
componenttext: This is Joe, John. That's a good question. No, it does not really signal a change in our strategy. We're being opportunistic wherever we can. I think our view is that we would like to take an ownership position and even a control position wherever we can. We do still strongly believe that we will need partners locally in all these markets, especially a market like India. So it doesn't -- the change in NDTV had more to do with that specifics of that deal than it did any kind of change in strategy.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And separately, with the dispute related to the affiliates, are renewal negotiations behind you? I assume that loyalty to your brands from consumers became pretty evident to you guys. And so as you think about future food renegotiations, does that allow y
componenttext: And separately, with the dispute related to the affiliates, are renewal negotiations behind you? I assume that loyalty to your brands from consumers became pretty evident to you guys. And so as you think about future food renegotiations, does that allow you to be maybe more aggressive knowing that consumers appear to be willing to switch providers? Or maybe has the bar been set meaning, you have something like maybe 90% conviction? And what do you expect in terms of the monthly fee, given the recent deals?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, this is John. Good morning. Well, we certainly were gratified to see the loyalty to our brand, especially the Food Network brand. And to say that, that gratification would translate into more confidence going into future negotiations, I think t
componenttext: Yes, John, this is John. Good morning. Well, we certainly were gratified to see the loyalty to our brand, especially the Food Network brand. And to say that, that gratification would translate into more confidence going into future negotiations, I think that's a fair assumption, yes.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Karimzad of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Karimzad of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, an HGTV question and a bit on Travel. Over at HG, you did well in the first quarter on the ratings side. But it looks like on the schedule, you've increased the House Hunters' presence quite a bit. If you could give us some color on what w
componenttext: I guess, first, an HGTV question and a bit on Travel. Over at HG, you did well in the first quarter on the ratings side. But it looks like on the schedule, you've increased the House Hunters' presence quite a bit. If you could give us some color on what was the reasoning behind that because it is one of your higher viewership shows. And then on the Travel side, ad revenue backing in. It looks like it did nicely maybe kind of high single, low doubles there, but not quite as well as say, Food even though both of them had very good audience growth in '09 into first quarter '10. Can you give us a sense of maybe as you transition the sales force to your side, are there some low-hanging fruit there that they weren't tapping?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. House Hunters has been a perennial success story, breakout hit for HGTV. It has for over 10 years and continues to do so. Of course, we've expanded the genre now to include House Hunters International. And the positioning of it on the schedul
componenttext: Sure, Brian. House Hunters has been a perennial success story, breakout hit for HGTV. It has for over 10 years and continues to do so. Of course, we've expanded the genre now to include House Hunters International. And the positioning of it on the schedule allows us to put new series on the back end of it to introduce the audience to those series. And so what we're seeing is the success of new series such as Holmes on Homes and Selling New York. And even our First-Time Home Buyers' block have all benefited from the boost of audience that House Hunters creates. So think of House Hunters as really a catalyst on our schedule, creating an opportunity for us to create and grow new franchises. And the team at HGTV has done a terrific job over the last years and making that really pay off for them, particularly with Holmes on Homes, which saw a 30% growth year-over-year in the time period in the first quarter with the introduction of the new season. In terms of Travel, we took over the ad sales, as we said earlier, at the end of March. And I guess the way we think about it is in our portfolio, Travel Channel is one of our three crown jewels. It will get all of the attention, if not even a little more attention, since it's a bit of a start-up for us as a Food Network or an HGTV. It's not anything short of a top priority for us. We promoted one of our young stars in the Ad Sales department, Greg Regis, to manage the Ad Sales group. We made some terrific hires for the Ad Sales team. We've effectively created an entire Ad Sales team dedicated to the success of Travel Channel. And I can tell you this, in the first quarter, prior to us taking it over, the DR [depositary receipt] component of Travel Channel was upwards of 30% and the DR component of Travel under this, our Ad Sales team will be something closer to the mid-single digits as we're pushing much, much more aggressively in the scatter. And we'll be pushing more aggressively in the upfront marketplace.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Alexia Quadrani of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Alexia Quadrani of JPMorgan.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned, I think, in your prepared comments that the scatter was up mid-teens over scatter in the second quarter. Can you tell us how that compares to the average scatter pricing during the first quarter? And I guess any further thoughts you may hav
componenttext: You mentioned, I think, in your prepared comments that the scatter was up mid-teens over scatter in the second quarter. Can you tell us how that compares to the average scatter pricing during the first quarter? And I guess any further thoughts you may have on how the upfront may turn out this year.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Alexia. We are seeing an improving scatter marketplace each month of the year. And on the second quarter, as you noted, we're seeing mid-teens, I should say, growth in scatter pricing. That's up of high single digit CPM growth in the first quarter.
componenttext: Sure, Alexia. We are seeing an improving scatter marketplace each month of the year. And on the second quarter, as you noted, we're seeing mid-teens, I should say, growth in scatter pricing. That's up of high single digit CPM growth in the first quarter. So it's doubled in terms of year-over-year growth. In terms of our scatter pricing to last year's upfront, it's moved now in the second quarter to 25% on top of last year's upfront marketplace. And that is continuing to improve week-to-week. So barring something unforeseen, we anticipate there being a significant improvement in the upfront marketplace, simply because the advertisers are paying such a premium right now to get into the scatter marketplace. And we believe that will translate into volume growth for the cable industry in the upfront upwards of 20%. And in terms of Scripps Networks, I would anticipate our CPM growth in the upcoming upfront would be in the mid- to high singles, leaning towards the high singles.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And is there anyone vertical? Or is it really across the board, driving the strength in the scatter?
componenttext: And is there anyone vertical? Or is it really across the board, driving the strength in the scatter?

componenttext: For us, it's the same category that typically offer our strength. For us, the Food category is the number one category across all of our networks, consumer products, retail, financial and automotive. Probably the most interesting growth story year-over-year is automotive.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010

componenttext: And would you say travel has a lot of overlap in terms of the client base?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're beginning to develop that, some of that overlap, if you will. There was such a reliance on DR in the past, and now we're able to introduce Travel to a variety of our other clients. And as we work with Laureen Ong to improve the female composit
componenttext: Well, we're beginning to develop that, some of that overlap, if you will. There was such a reliance on DR in the past, and now we're able to introduce Travel to a variety of our other clients. And as we work with Laureen Ong to improve the female composition of that network then we anticipate moving more aggressively into the consumer product goods that today are not all that well represented on the network.

componenttext: Well, right now, Fine Living distribution is sitting at about $58 million, and I anticipate that we will step into that footprint pretty much, if not 100%, close to that.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Helfstein of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Helfstein of Oppenheimer.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: So just thinking about the strength of the advertising, which is the best in the industry right now, I mean, how much of this do you think is a recognition of the effectiveness of advertising on your networks versus your ratings strength versus an improve
componenttext: So just thinking about the strength of the advertising, which is the best in the industry right now, I mean, how much of this do you think is a recognition of the effectiveness of advertising on your networks versus your ratings strength versus an improved pricing environment? And then just secondly, if we think about the international opportunity longer term, Discovery gets about a third of their revenue internationally, granted they've been at it internationally for a long time. What do you think the right long-term goal is for international as a percent of Lifestyle Media revenues?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start, and then I'll let Joe grab the international question. Great question on our ad growth. We're certainly very proud of our Ad Sales team to deliver 14% growth. And you make a very good point. For many, many years now, we've been talking a
componenttext: Well, I'll start, and then I'll let Joe grab the international question. Great question on our ad growth. We're certainly very proud of our Ad Sales team to deliver 14% growth. And you make a very good point. For many, many years now, we've been talking about the method that Scripps Networks approaches the ad marketplace, which is really selling the engagement that our audiences have with our programming and how commercials that run within our programming tend to work very, very well for advertisers. Because in many cases, our audiences look at the advertising as part of the programming. It helps complete the cycle, if you will, of the inspiration the programming creates. And then the advertising provides a place for an audience to make good on that inspiration. But also going along with that, we invested somewhat in programming and marketing this year as was noted in our earlier prepared remarks. And we also pushed forward our advertising guarantees, our ratings guarantees. We bet on the upside based on that investment in programming and marketing. And thankfully, the ratings came in and met those higher and more aggressive ratings guarantees. And as a result, higher ratings meeting a stronger marketplace and then being able to monetize the engagement of our audience really served us well in this quarter.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on international?
componenttext: And then on international?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason, this is Joe. On international, we certainly look at Discovery and Viacom and others in terms of the composition of their revenue and how much is international. We certainly think of them as great benchmarks. But frankly, we'd be happy with hal
componenttext: Yes, Jason, this is Joe. On international, we certainly look at Discovery and Viacom and others in terms of the composition of their revenue and how much is international. We certainly think of them as great benchmarks. But frankly, we'd be happy with half of what they get. We don't have a pre-established goal for this. I think there are great opportunities for our programming. And we've been very warmly received around the globe. But these are deals you do one at a time. We're more interested in making a very good return on the investment than we are in the absolute size of the business at this point. But that said, we think there's plenty of room to run. And as our plans develop and as we execute on some of these opportunities, we'll probably get a little more definitive about where we think it will ultimately go.

componenttext: Yes, Anthony, without getting into any detail on the affiliate agreements, of course, the terms are confidential, including the term of the contracts themselves. But we have no significant activity this year beyond a single operator related to Travel. And then after that, we don't expect any major activity around Food for a couple of years and around HGTV for three years.
