headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: I know it's the sort of after the fact and you indicated this coming into the first quarter. But the $11 million or so on spending against the affiliate renewals, I mean, really the dispute was just with Cablevision now. They've only got 3 million subs. A
componenttext: I know it's the sort of after the fact and you indicated this coming into the first quarter. But the $11 million or so on spending against the affiliate renewals, I mean, really the dispute was just with Cablevision now. They've only got 3 million subs. And so I guess the first question is, is the $11 million just against Cablevision? Because that seems like a lot of money relative to the revenue that you get from them.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll answer that, and then I'll let John add some color. Indeed, it was related to that one dispute. But that's a very valuable market. And advertising is not always cheap, especially in New York markets. So John, you have any color you want to add?
componenttext: Well, I'll answer that, and then I'll let John add some color. Indeed, it was related to that one dispute. But that's a very valuable market. And advertising is not always cheap, especially in New York markets. So John, you have any color you want to add?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: It's true, and you also have to consider that we really had no choice but to bring in the rate with Cablevision at the same level on our rate card as we have with others because due to MFN considerations, we had to protect the rate cards. So the spending
componenttext: It's true, and you also have to consider that we really had no choice but to bring in the rate with Cablevision at the same level on our rate card as we have with others because due to MFN considerations, we had to protect the rate cards. So the spending against Cablevision had a multiplying effect were we not successful, and we were successful. So the spending made sense.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the Travel transition expenses, I mean, typically, when we see acquisitions either there's restructuring charges or things are capitalized. And in your case, you're running [ph] (1:04:45) these expenses through. I mean, can you just give us a
componenttext: And then on the Travel transition expenses, I mean, typically, when we see acquisitions either there's restructuring charges or things are capitalized. And in your case, you're running [ph] (1:04:45) these expenses through. I mean, can you just give us a sense of what the spending is? I mean, it's a pretty large dollar amount, but obviously it's a big deal.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, and I can assure you we're following all the rules we could follow. We are probably a little more conservative than some companies. You don't have as much room to capitalize costs in a transition. A lot of these are related to job terminations and s
componenttext: Well, and I can assure you we're following all the rules we could follow. We are probably a little more conservative than some companies. You don't have as much room to capitalize costs in a transition. A lot of these are related to job terminations and some contract breakage. There was the agreements that they'd executed with Discovery. There are charges related to transitioning those away from Discovery. So it's a number of things that we didn't think had a future benefit to us. So we ran them through.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly upfront strategy. I mean, you talked about high single digit CPMs, is this an upfront where at that price you're taking as much volume as you can even though -- I mean, scatter pricing right now is awfully healthy. And so I guess a lo
componenttext: And then just lastly upfront strategy. I mean, you talked about high single digit CPMs, is this an upfront where at that price you're taking as much volume as you can even though -- I mean, scatter pricing right now is awfully healthy. And so I guess a lot of us starts to get worried what the world looks like a year from now. Can we maintain this level of scatter pricing a year from now? Do you manage your upfront sellout and restrain it so that you have enough inventory to take advantage of scattering next year? Or do you have enough DR and other things out there that you just go for volume in the upfront? So any comments on that would be helpful.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a little bit early there to make that call, to be honest with you. But as the scatter goes, the pendulum begins swinging towards the upfront in terms of activity. Typically, we're looking at somewhere in the range of 45% to 50% that we put in
componenttext: I think it's a little bit early there to make that call, to be honest with you. But as the scatter goes, the pendulum begins swinging towards the upfront in terms of activity. Typically, we're looking at somewhere in the range of 45% to 50% that we put into an upfront, and that will be our starting point. And then based on the pricing increases that we can achieve, based on the condition of the scatter market at that time, we'll make a call as to where we'll end up. But I wouldn't anticipate us making a bit [ph] (1:06:49) off of a percentage of inventory within a range of 4% to 5%.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to the Travel Channel transition and the catalyst that you see there coming up over the next year, where are you in terms of your investments and programming? And at what point do we start seeing a slate that reflects those investments?
componenttext: With regard to the Travel Channel transition and the catalyst that you see there coming up over the next year, where are you in terms of your investments and programming? And at what point do we start seeing a slate that reflects those investments?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the good news is that we hired one of the best in the business, and Laureen Ong to come in and work with the team and create the vision for growth. So it's more than just, in our minds, a programming slate per se as it is a concept to be developed a
componenttext: Well, the good news is that we hired one of the best in the business, and Laureen Ong to come in and work with the team and create the vision for growth. So it's more than just, in our minds, a programming slate per se as it is a concept to be developed around a Travel programming and branding initiative that will require that we have two to three, perhaps four to five series that become very, very well known and become definitive for creating the brand and creates a destination point much like Food Network and HGTV have become and DIY. And so the slate that we're running through right now was the development from last year. So the most recent series, including Food Wars is now -- those are now the last of the 2010 slate coming out of '09. And now, we have a significant programming budget of $50 million put against the development of a new slate. We have Laureen and her team and a chance to really think through how to do that. And perhaps most importantly, we have the expertise of our programming geniuses at the Food Network and HGTV and others, who will work together with Travel and see what learnings we can develop from our other success stories. So that in creating the Travel brand that will be manifested through programming success stories. We don't have to relearn some of the techniques that we've picked up along the way.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Would you say then September might be too early to start seeing a transitioning slate and it's more of  a 2011 situation there? Or can we start seeing things by the fall?
componenttext: Would you say then September might be too early to start seeing a transitioning slate and it's more of  a 2011 situation there? Or can we start seeing things by the fall?

componenttextpreview: I think you'll start to see some things by the fall. But I think the majority of it would be first quarter 2011.
componenttext: I think you'll start to see some things by the fall. But I think the majority of it would be first quarter 2011.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about what you're doing on a skunkworks basis on the interactive advertising side with EBIT and all that, given how committed your users are to some of the linear channel side. It seems like that might get even further amplified with interact
componenttext: Can you talk about what you're doing on a skunkworks basis on the interactive advertising side with EBIT and all that, given how committed your users are to some of the linear channel side. It seems like that might get even further amplified with interactive. And then could you talk more about what you're doing to allow people more mobile access to your programming, given that various priorities that come into play there?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-06-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, ironically, one of our biggest initiatives along the lines of interactive advertising is with our partner, Cablevision, who after we were beyond the dispute from earlier this year, we partnered with Cablevision on an experimental platform through a
componenttext: Well, ironically, one of our biggest initiatives along the lines of interactive advertising is with our partner, Cablevision, who after we were beyond the dispute from earlier this year, we partnered with Cablevision on an experimental platform through a third-party vendor called ActiveVideo on a new interactive advertising platform. And it looks very promising. I just had an update on it earlier this week, very interesting indeed. We also have a distribution deal with a website called www.5min.com. It's m-i-n as in minute. www.5min.com where they are now distributing videos from all of our channels, and then we're selling that distributed network around the world. And we're seeing an amazing uptick in pushing our videos out in this distributed model, so that we're seeing ad revenue against videos that rivals the revenue on our own website through www.5min.com. And then in terms of mobile, our friends at Travel were in many ways further along than we were in thinking about mobile. And so we're really working closely with them in developing a mobile expertise. Food Network -- and both HGTV and Food Network have developed some interesting applications for iPhone and iPad. And we'll work together between our application development and the mobile expertise of Travel to see what opportunity we can create.

componenttext: Sure. I think we mentioned in the opening comments that our view is that we're not going to do anything at this moment in terms of the cash balance that we have. We will maintain a certain amount in the business. Our priorities are as they've always been, making sure that we have adequate programming on the one hand. But outside of the core of the business, we still have an interest in the Food Network stub and beyond that, international opportunities. I think they're probably the top two priorities. So that's how we think about it at this moment. We don't think we have enough of a cash balance to worry about having too much on hand.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kay, and good morning, all, and thanks for joining us. We'll start the conference call today with comments from Ken Lowe, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Joe NeCastro, Chief Financial Officer. Our prepared remarks should take about 15 or s
componenttext:
Thank you, Kay, and good morning, all, and thanks for joining us. We'll start the conference call today with comments from Ken Lowe, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Joe NeCastro, Chief Financial Officer. Our prepared remarks should take about 15 or so minutes. Then we'll open it up for questions. Also on the call is John Lansing, President of the Scripps Networks Operating Division; and Lori Hickok, Executive Vice President of Finance.
Let me remind you, if you prefer to listen in via the Internet, go to our website, click on Investor Relations and find the microphone icon on the landing page. An audio archive of today's conference call will be available on the website later today, and we'll leave it there for a couple of weeks, so you can access it at your convenience. 
Our discussion this morning will contain certain forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from those predicted. And some of the factors that may cause results to differ are set forth in our publicly filed documents, including our Form 10-K. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Ken.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. As always, we clearly appreciate your interest in Scripps Networks Interactive. The second quarter and first half of the year were outstanding for the company and its shareholders by
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. As always, we clearly appreciate your interest in Scripps Networks Interactive. 
The second quarter and first half of the year were outstanding for the company and its shareholders by just about every measure. Here are the headlines: Industry-leading ad revenue growth; exceptionally strong growth in affiliate fee revenues; solid viewership at all our networks, including the new Cooking Channel; and very encouraging performance at Travel Channel, which is now pretty much integrated and I'm happy to report exceeding our expectations. All these factors contributed to the positive operating results that we reported this morning. We're right on track for an excellent 2010 and prospects for 2011 are looking very good as well.
With the tremendous popularity of the Food Network, steady viewership at HGTV and growing appeal of the Travel Channel, we've been able to take full advantage of the current ad recovery. The strength of the current scatter marketplace drove ad sales higher during the quarter and contributed to the decisive success that we've had in this year's upfront. We finished the upfront at or near the top of cable and pricing, and we grew total volumes sold well beyond last year's level. Provided the economy holds, this strong upfront bodes well for ad sales in the coming year. 
As for our affiliate fee revenues, the strong growth in the second quarter and first half of the year is directly attributable to the improved carriage agreements that we negotiated for Food Network and HGTV at the end of 2009. Our new distribution contracts reflect the value that we've created at our networks, and importantly, layer in a dependable source of revenue growth for years to come. So all in all, very positive operating results for the second quarter and first half.
There were other highlights during the quarter as well, not the least of which was the launch and initial success of the Cooking Channel. Our newest brand really surged out of the box with its debut Memorial Day weekend and has continued to gain momentum, both  in terms of viewership and its acceptance as a variable advertising platform. Compared with Fine Living, Cooking Channel viewership among adults 25 to 54 is up anywhere from 30% to 100% depending on the daypart. Cooking resonated with their advertisers from the day we started selling it. And as for programming, well, we've succeeded in differentiating the Cooking Channel from its sister network by filling out its schedule with a healthy mix of new and archived shows. And we're featuring fresh, new talent and we're giving the network a unique look and feel. I hope you've had a chance to see it.
We've also succeeded in converting all of Fine Living's 58 million households to the Cooking Channel brand, which makes Cooking the most widely distributed launch of a new network in the history of cable and satellite television. No small accomplishment there, I should say. And we're very encouraged by Cooking Channel's performance in the early going, especially considering the modest investment we made to bring this brand quickly to market.
Now the news is equally as good at the Travel Channel. For the most part, the network has been fully integrated, which puts us in an excellent position to market the brand in the upfront. We quickly and successfully expanded Travel's advertising base by really putting together a top-notch ad sales team, by leveraging our relationships and actively cross promoting the brand across all of our networks. Now that's resulted in a higher percentage of top-tier advertisers in a broader range of categories. So our success is evident both onscreen and in our operating results.
On the programming front, viewership at Travel Channel grew solidly during the second quarter, thanks to the standouts like Man v. Food with Adam Richman and Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations. Speaking of Anthony, we have some very good news about him during the quarter. We signed a new talent agreement, which means you'll be seeing Anthony on the Travel Channel for some time to come. We think that's very good news for us, for Anthony and certainly for his many, many fans. And there's more. Laureen Ong has been busy building her team and molding a programming and marketing strategy, that's destined to transform the Travel Channel brand and build audiences. Now you'll start seeing some of their handiwork in the months to come. So stay tuned there. 
Food Network, meanwhile, continues on a roll. Food now ranks consistently among the top 10 most watched networks in cable among adults 25 to 54. For example, during one week in June, the Food Network made it in the top five on the strength of the season's premiere of Next Food Network Star. It was the highest rated premiere of a new series in the network's history. And it helped us successfully launch a couple of news shows like Cupcake Wars and Food Feuds both of which have been doing very, very well.
Making good on our promise to be a leading source of entertaining and informative content for food fanatics everywhere. Food Network, Cooking Channel, the Food Network Magazine and our growing portfolio of interactive businesses gives us a stable of desirable content platforms in the Food category. Internationally, Food Network is proving to be a hit in the U.K., where we reached about 10 million viewers via Sky. And since its launch last November, Food Network has rapidly become a formidable competitor to food channels that have been established in the U.K. market for a number of years. We're really creating a whole new cadre of Food Network fans.
A word about the Food Network Magazine. Circulation has reached about 1.3 million. And perhaps more importantly, it's now profitable. That's a full two years ahead of when we expected it to be in the black. It's truly a testament of the power of the Food Network brand and the intense consumer interest in food as a content category. Well, we hats off to our partners at Hearst, who have done a fantastic job of establishing Food Network Magazine as a newsstand staple. 
At HGTV, second quarter viewership among adults 25 to 54 moved up three notches in the ranking from 16th to 13th. The improvement came on the strength of Design Star, which proved its worth once again by lifting overall viewership of the network and serving really as a great lead-in to new store shows. Color Splash Miami, which we schedule to follow Design Star on Sunday nights has also done very well. Holmes on Homes, House Hunters and House Hunters International also continued to deliver solid audiences. 
Also in the Home category, weekend ratings at DIY Network grew solidly during the second quarter, especially among men who tune in to watch shows like Cool Tools, Man Caves and Garage Mahal. For DIY, weekends are primetime. And adult men 25 to 54 is the demographic advertisers value during those dayparts.
Online, our Lifestyle Media websites continue to be leaders in their respective content categories, aggregating large and growing communities of users. Our websites and growing list of interactive mobile applications deliver useful information and solution-based content that makes them desirable destinations. At hgtv.com, we've been focusing on creating innovative online tools and applications using designer portfolio and Rate My Space. As a result, we've seen substantial growth in some user metrics. For all of our Home category sites combined for example, page views in June were up 38% compared with the prior year.
In addition, the free HGTV To Go application we created for the iPad and iPhone generated 14,000 downloads on each device in the first two weeks after it was launched in June. Our objective is to deliver our brand of lifestyle content via whatever interactive platform consumers choose. 
And finally at Shopzilla, our efforts to competitively reposition the business are really beginning to bear some fruit. The all-important metric of direct leads to merchants continued to grow during the second quarter, which tells us that we've made some progress differentiating the brand from other online comparison shopping businesses and improving the online shopping experience for consumers. 
Put it all together, and you have a media company that's really hitting on all cylinders, led by industry-leading ad and affiliate revenue growth, solid viewership at all our brands, which actively engaged upscale audiences in the lucrative Home, Food and Travel content categories, our growing international presence and positive signs that we're turning the corner at our Online Comparison Shopping businesses. Scripps Networks Interactive is well positioned for growth and is committed to continuing to create value for our shareholders. 
With that, let me now turn it over to Joe.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ken, and good morning, everyone. I'm sure you've all seen the press release by now this morning. So I won't go over the second quarter results in detail. Instead, I'll hit on some of the highlights and provide a little more color on some of the dy
componenttext:
Thanks, Ken, and good morning, everyone. I'm sure you've all seen the press release by now this morning. So I won't go over the second quarter results in detail. Instead, I'll hit on some of the highlights and provide a little more color on some of the dynamics that drove the quarter. 
First on advertising. The continuing recovery in advertising has had its obvious positive effect. The scatter marketplace continued to be very strong during the three-month period, as it has been for most of the year so far. Scatter versus scatter pricing continues to be up in the mid to high teens over 2009, and scatter versus last year's upfront was up as much as 25% to 30%. As I'm sure you know, the strength in scatter found its way into this year's upfront for both broadcast and cable. 
For Scripps Networks, that translated into solid growth in CPM pricing and a 30% increase in volume compared to last year. Given the strength of the market, we committed a bit more inventory than last year, which puts our upfront sell-out rate at just north of 50% across all our brands. We went into the upfront with lots of momentum including growth in viewership at all our networks, high expectations and considerable buzz around the launch of the Cooking Channel, and a clear opportunity to expand the advertising base at the Travel Channel. 
As far as we can determine, once all is said and done, we came out of the upfront at or near the top of our competitive set once again. As a result, the outlook for advertising for the balance of the year and for most of 2011 looks positive, provided the economy continues to improve. The only negative for advertising in the second quarter has since turned positive. The growth rate for digital advertisings slowed to about 3%, which we take to be a continuing effect of the housing downturn at our home-related websites. The good news is that we've seen a marked improvement in digital ad sales during the past six weeks.
Turning to our affiliate revenues. The exceptionally strong growth is largely a function of the new contracts we negotiated for Food Network and for HGTV. Growth in distribution at all of our networks also contributed however. Remember that our new contracts provided for a significant step up in rates in the first year for a significant portion of our distribution base, particularly for Food Network. Growth in affiliate revenues, while meaningful for the balance of the contracts will moderate from current year's outsized increases starting in 2011. 
One other highlight from the income statement worth noting is the strong performance and strong improvement in equity earnings from affiliates. The 43% growth rate reflects the improved advertising market in Canada and the growing contribution from Food Network Magazine, which as Ken noted, is profitable two years ahead of schedule. 
Excluding the effects of the Travel Channel acquisition, our consolidated margins expanded by about 170 basis points during the quarter. The margin improved despite our need to restore our marketing budget this year to support all our brands. Our programming costs have also been higher, due to some seasonally heavy write-downs relative to last year and accelerated amortization costs that were related to our Cooking Channel rebranding and launch.
We expect programming expenses to moderate for the balance of the year, now that the rebranding is complete. Programming costs are still expected to fall within the range we've provided previously. Non-programming costs, including the restored marketing budgets, were higher during the second quarter and first half of the year. But we expect those expenses to moderate during the back half as well. As a result, we now expect full year non-programming cost to fall closer to the lower end of our guidance. 
As for the Travel Channel integration, we're pretty much complete. Through the first half of the year, we've incurred about $24 million in onetime transition cost, most of which were related to the termination of operating agreements that the network had with Discovery. We still have a little more work to do, so some additional transition costs will fall in the back half of the year. We still expect the onetime integration cost to finish the year toward the lower end of our $30 million to $40 million guidance range.
The good news is that Travel Channel results year-to-date are exceeding our expectations. And the acquisition will be decisively accretive this year, both to segment profit and earnings per share. 
Finally, as we noted in the press release, our net income of $0.63 included a tax benefit in discontinued operations and the onetime transition cost for Travel. Our adjusted net income was $0.59 per share, after backing up both of those items. 
Our balance sheet continues to be strong. We finished the quarter with $331 million in cash and the $884 million in long-term debt we incurred last year to complete the acquisition of our controlling interest in the Travel Channel. That debt has a five-year term, so we won't have any obligations other than interest payments for the next four-plus years. 
In the near term, we'll be using our cash for the continued development of our network brands and related businesses and to support our international expansion efforts. Our preference is to create value for shareholders by strengthening our competitive position as a leader in lifestyle programming and content. 
With that, operator, we're ready to take any questions.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: And just on the Travel Channel, it sounds like you guys are making some great inroads there. I know one of the big differentiators of Travel versus your legacy networks is they have a lot more direct response advertising. Could you give as an update, I th
componenttext: And just on the Travel Channel, it sounds like you guys are making some great inroads there. I know one of the big differentiators of Travel versus your legacy networks is they have a lot more direct response advertising. Could you give as an update, I think, on how that is -- I know it's only -- it hasn't been a very long period of time yet. But how is that it's trending versus what it has historically? And where do you think the percentage of direct response advertising can get to maybe by year end?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. When we took over selling the network, the direct response represented upwards of 30% of the inventory sold. And of course for our big networks, that percentage tends to range between 5% and 8%. Our ad sales team has done a fantastic job replacing a
componenttext: Sure. When we took over selling the network, the direct response represented upwards of 30% of the inventory sold. And of course for our big networks, that percentage tends to range between 5% and 8%. Our ad sales team has done a fantastic job replacing a great deal of that BR with spot business. And as a result, we're seeing excellent growth on the ad side for Travel. Probably the best indicator, Alexia, is the upfront negotiations for Travel, where our team succeeded in adding 30 new advertisers to the network from the year before and increased the volume in the upfront up to 60% over last year.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: And just one last question more on the affiliate revenues. Joe, I think you mentioned the growth obviously will moderate in year two after the initial step-up particularly at Food. Could you just give us some color, a range of where you think that growth
componenttext: And just one last question more on the affiliate revenues. Joe, I think you mentioned the growth obviously will moderate in year two after the initial step-up particularly at Food. Could you just give us some color, a range of where you think that growth should be? Is it high single digit, low double digit in terms of where it will moderate to next year?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: It's probably too early to give that kind of guidance on the outyears. I think, what we'll try to do is at the end of the year, when we set our guidance ranges for next year, we'll give you some flavor. But I think, it's fair to say it's not going to be j
componenttext: It's probably too early to give that kind of guidance on the outyears. I think, what we'll try to do is at the end of the year, when we set our guidance ranges for next year, we'll give you some flavor. But I think, it's fair to say it's not going to be just CPI. It will be a little more favorable than that.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Eric Handler, MKM Partners.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Eric Handler, MKM Partners.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: I think I may have missed this. But on HGTV, the ad revenue seemingly decelerated quite a bit quarter-over-quarter. Can you give a reason for that? And then secondly, in terms of your International business, what's the appetite now for deals among some of
componenttext: I think I may have missed this. But on HGTV, the ad revenue seemingly decelerated quite a bit quarter-over-quarter. Can you give a reason for that? And then secondly, in terms of your International business, what's the appetite now for deals among some of the partners that you've been talking with?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: This is John, Eric. We're seeing HGTV holding up for the mid-singles in terms of ad growth year-over-year. I think that's really holding steady with where we began the year, and we expect it probably will finish up about there fairly steadily.
componenttext: This is John, Eric. We're seeing HGTV holding up for the mid-singles in terms of ad growth year-over-year. I think that's really holding steady with where we began the year, and we expect it probably will finish up about there fairly steadily.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, on international, I think it's fair to say that we've been really gratified with how much interest there is in our categories, in our content, in our brands. Once we announced that we were not going to go any further with NDTV in India, I think with
componenttext: Eric, on international, I think it's fair to say that we've been really gratified with how much interest there is in our categories, in our content, in our brands. Once we announced that we were not going to go any further with NDTV in India, I think within the next week we received probably a dozen calls from potential partners there. And we have since spent some time on the ground there and we're trying to narrow the field down and select the best one. That's obviously just one market but a very important one for us. The content continues to do well in Europe, as we continue to expand our footprint there. So we don't see any kind of dampening for demand for, as I said, our content, our brands.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente, Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente, Barclays Capital.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: I just have two questions. One question is, I know that this may be a long way off, but I know you have another 25% of your Food Network distribution that expires at the end of next year. Correct me if I'm mistaken on that. But I just wonder if you are in
componenttext: I just have two questions. One question is, I know that this may be a long way off, but I know you have another 25% of your Food Network distribution that expires at the end of next year. Correct me if I'm mistaken on that. But I just wonder if you are in active talks to possibly renew that contract any earlier than the end of next year? Just given that you've locked in so much of the other portion of the distribution. And then, the other part of that question would be, if you were to lock it in earlier or if you were to wait until the end of next year, would the terms look a lot like the terms that you've already agreed upon with the other distributors?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Anthony, this is John, I'll take that. You're correct. We have 25% of the distribution up for negotiation at the end of 2011. It is a bit early. Of course, we would be pleased in order to get it done early. And we would look for every opportunity to do th
componenttext: Anthony, this is John, I'll take that. You're correct. We have 25% of the distribution up for negotiation at the end of 2011. It is a bit early. Of course, we would be pleased in order to get it done early. And we would look for every opportunity to do that, and we will continue so. But at this point, we have not had a chance or an opportunity to negotiate that any earlier. The terms, however, that we'll negotiate will look very much like, if not exactly like in terms of the economic terms of our other deals because we'll be negotiating the very same rate card that was negotiated for the other 75% of distribution at the end of 2009.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: The other question, I just thought maybe if you could update us on the Food Network minority stake. And any possibilities, how we should think about the possibilities that you could buy that stake in at any point? Is there any updates in terms of your con
componenttext: The other question, I just thought maybe if you could update us on the Food Network minority stake. And any possibilities, how we should think about the possibilities that you could buy that stake in at any point? Is there any updates in terms of your conversations or thoughts on that possibility?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: This is probably marks the 30th consecutive quarter we've talked about the potential for buying that. But you probably all saw the news with respect to the bankruptcy proceeding and the fact that another hearing, which was set for late this month has been
componenttext: This is probably marks the 30th consecutive quarter we've talked about the potential for buying that. But you probably all saw the news with respect to the bankruptcy proceeding and the fact that another hearing, which was set for late this month has been postponed until early or mid-October. We're very patient, obviously, but I would say, if I were thinking about this, obviously nothing will happen this year. And I think the first time we would ever really be having a meaningful dialogue about it will probably be mid next year. So we continue to be interested at a fair price. We would love to do it. We are engaged with the Tribune Company over other issues on a daily basis. We have quarterly calls with them. They know we're interested. I think their attention is on, and I think rightfully so, exiting from bankruptcy as soon as they can.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: So if nothing will happen this year, I guess it brings up the question, it begs the question of what else could you possibly do with your cash in the balance sheet, presuming that you have been saving some ammunition for that possibility? Is there a chanc
componenttext: So if nothing will happen this year, I guess it brings up the question, it begs the question of what else could you possibly do with your cash in the balance sheet, presuming that you have been saving some ammunition for that possibility? Is there a chance that in lieu of that, that you guys might consider returning capital to shareholders? Or is this a situation where you just like to maintain as much flexibility as possible in case this comes up?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're going to try and walk a little bit of a tight rope between those two. As we have said repeatedly, we like the flexibility that a strong balance sheet gives us. So we're not likely to drain all of our flexibility in an attempt to return cash
componenttext: I think we're going to try and walk a little bit of a tight rope between those two. As we have said repeatedly, we like the flexibility that a strong balance sheet gives us. So we're not likely to drain all of our flexibility in an attempt to return cash to shareholders. That said, we understand that we're not in business to hold onto cash and we won't. The debt that we have cannot be repaid just by its very terms. So it's not like we're going to service that debt or pay it all back. So I only can tell you is that it's actively considered by the Board. We look very closely at our projections for how much cash we're going to have by year end and by early next year. And it's under active consideration, but there have been no decisions yet.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of Tom Eagan, Collins Stewart.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Tom Eagan, Collins Stewart.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Looking back at your recent affiliate fee renewal negotiations, what do you hear, if anything, from the operators about they're being somewhat constrained by having to pay retrans fees to all of the broadcasters?
componenttext: Looking back at your recent affiliate fee renewal negotiations, what do you hear, if anything, from the operators about they're being somewhat constrained by having to pay retrans fees to all of the broadcasters?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tom, this is John. Of course, the issue is real for the distributors in terms of extra demands for cash from broadcasters. But for us, the arguments are very simple one in that, it's just a quotient of the audience that we deliver compared with the
componenttext: Sure, Tom, this is John. Of course, the issue is real for the distributors in terms of extra demands for cash from broadcasters. But for us, the arguments are very simple one in that, it's just a quotient of the audience that we deliver compared with the percentage of the revenue pie that we take out. And even though we were successful in drastically improving our position, it's still fair to say that our bigger networks could still have room for further growth in the future, based on the audience that we deliver on a nightly basis and that will continue to be the case. I think any network that is not necessarily delivering the audience or the high-quality audience as we are, may face greater pressure because of the demands coming from the retrans side of the pie. But as long as HGTV and Food Network, Travel, DIY, Cooking Channel and GAC are delivering, the audience are delivering, I think we stand in good stead to continue to grow our share of the pie.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: And you mentioned that you had a sizable step-up this year with it moderating sequentially after that. Was that more your idea or their idea? What made you come to that kind of process?
componenttext: And you mentioned that you had a sizable step-up this year with it moderating sequentially after that. Was that more your idea or their idea? What made you come to that kind of process?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the step-up that we had was obviously very big. And so in terms of moderating thereafter, anything below that would be moderating. So it really was just an agreement in the various negotiations as to the length of the term and how long the various c
componenttext: Well, the step-up that we had was obviously very big. And so in terms of moderating thereafter, anything below that would be moderating. So it really was just an agreement in the various negotiations as to the length of the term and how long the various contracts may last. But you almost have to moderate the term moderate because of the high degree of the step-up was in the first year.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly, is any other assets on the balance sheet from the Fine Living program?
componenttext: And then just lastly, is any other assets on the balance sheet from the Fine Living program?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: No. Basically, we have some asset but not -- we've basically transferred what we could use to the program and that's part of what you saw with some of the seasonal write-off we discussed.
componenttext: No. Basically, we have some asset but not -- we've basically transferred what we could use to the program and that's part of what you saw with some of the seasonal write-off we discussed.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Brian Karimzad, Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Brian Karimzad, Goldman Sachs.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to get back to HGTV for a second. The reported revenue growth there was 12% in the first quarter, and as they sell, the 6% as you pointed out earlier. If the advertising revenue growth was consistent in both quarters, can you give some color then on
componenttext: Just to get back to HGTV for a second. The reported revenue growth there was 12% in the first quarter, and as they sell, the 6% as you pointed out earlier. If the advertising revenue growth was consistent in both quarters, can you give some color then on what did decelerate? And whether any onetime maybe affiliate revenue benefits there in the first quarter? If you can fill that a bit, it would be helpful.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: I can fill that in. The difference in the second quarter was we had some rating softness in April and May that resulted in some advertising liability that we're now recovering after a positive recovery in June and into July, we're seeing with the introduc
componenttext: I can fill that in. The difference in the second quarter was we had some rating softness in April and May that resulted in some advertising liability that we're now recovering after a positive recovery in June and into July, we're seeing with the introduction of Design Star as a new programming this summer. So we're back on a stronger footing in terms of ratings than we were in the early part of the second quarter.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the talent side, I knew you renewed with Anthony Bourdain at Travel. Paula Deen, I think her contract was up at the end of May, and my sense is that wasn't renewed with the network. I know she's one of many spices that make up the rub of the F
componenttext: And then on the talent side, I knew you renewed with Anthony Bourdain at Travel. Paula Deen, I think her contract was up at the end of May, and my sense is that wasn't renewed with the network. I know she's one of many spices that make up the rub of the Food Network flavor there. But if you can give us a sense of how you're managing risk with the talents and your general approach there?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Not to comment specifically on the Paula Deen negotiation. It's still an open question in fact. But what Brooke Johnson and her team at Food Network do so well is they bring in new talent, develop new talent. Actually, even through the Next Food Network S
componenttext: Not to comment specifically on the Paula Deen negotiation. It's still an open question in fact. But what Brooke Johnson and her team at Food Network do so well is they bring in new talent, develop new talent. Actually, even through the Next Food Network Star, which literally creates stars for the networks, including one of the network's biggest stars today, Guy Fieri, which was a winner of that contest. And they managed the talent development really well, and as they grow in popularity and other bigger opportunities come along, we work with them as best as we can in to make sure that we can both prosper. And we've seen that with Rachael Ray, we've seen that with Guy Fieri, we've seen that Paula Deen, and we'll continue to see that. And so our strategy is to make the Food Network a great place to develop talent and a great place for successful talent to want to stay for as long as it's good for both parties.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: On the seasonal program write-downs, was there any disproportionate amount at HGTV? I know you had a number of new series launches. It doesn't sound like the commentary on how those have gone has been as robust as what Food does or that just hasn't rolled
componenttext: On the seasonal program write-downs, was there any disproportionate amount at HGTV? I know you had a number of new series launches. It doesn't sound like the commentary on how those have gone has been as robust as what Food does or that just hasn't rolled that out yet?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Joe. I'll step into that one. I think the color there is that we will review programming as it makes sense. Typically, we'll do it at the end of the year. But as we go along, sometimes we'll find that certain things aren't working and don't
componenttext: Brian, this is Joe. I'll step into that one. I think the color there is that we will review programming as it makes sense. Typically, we'll do it at the end of the year. But as we go along, sometimes we'll find that certain things aren't working and don't have the life we thought. You're right in your suspicions that it was heavy with HGTV and the correlation with that and the rating softness that John talked about is not an accident. So that's really the nut of the story.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Doug Mitchelson, Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Doug Mitchelson, Deutsche Bank.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: A couple clarification in the question. So on the HGTV comments, not too get too much in the weeds here. But you said mid-single digits in 2Q and that would continue in the year. That was like cash advertising and it's just so the May goods are what we're
componenttext: A couple clarification in the question. So on the HGTV comments, not too get too much in the weeds here. But you said mid-single digits in 2Q and that would continue in the year. That was like cash advertising and it's just so the May goods are what we're seeing in the reported numbers? Is that what you are trying to imply with the May goods being earned back?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's exactly what we meant.
componenttext: Yes, that's exactly what we meant.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: One, I know the upfront was strong enough that its success was self evident and you talked about that. I was still hoping you could broaden the discussion a bit more there. Did you change the mix of advertisers at all this year? Was it broad based strengt
componenttext: One, I know the upfront was strong enough that its success was self evident and you talked about that. I was still hoping you could broaden the discussion a bit more there. Did you change the mix of advertisers at all this year? Was it broad based strength in all cannot categories including Home Improvement, were you able to move any new advertisers in? I guess I'm thinking of the core networks since you already discussed Travel.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, for instance, the rebranding of Fine Living to Cooking Channel was a great opportunity in the upfront to bring in some significant new dollars. In fact, our sales teams were successful in bringing nine advertisers in at $1 million or more for
componenttext: Sure. Well, for instance, the rebranding of Fine Living to Cooking Channel was a great opportunity in the upfront to bring in some significant new dollars. In fact, our sales teams were successful in bringing nine advertisers in at $1 million or more for the new network, Cooking Channel, and that was only 30 days after its launch. So that was part of the success story. And the volume growth on Cooking in the upfront over Fine Living is nearly 90%. Of course, Travel Channel, I discussed it earlier. But it allowed us to bring in a number of really solid advertisers that otherwise were not represented on Travel Channel. The CPG category particularly was underrepresented on Travel Channel, and we were able to bring a significant amount of that to bear. And then the strength overall of DIY and HGTV and the Home category and what we perceive to be the slowly improving Home category overall, albeit somewhat bumpy, we still see advertisers, the major advertisers betting on the future there again, and we're benefiting from that as well. So all in all, our growth, I think Joe mentioned in his commentary, in volume in this year's upfront was 30%. The cable marketplace overall grew 18%. And we're able to create that volume growth almost entirely on new business, new advertisers and rating points. We took a very slightly bit more of inventory into the marketplace, 2% to 3%. But mostly the volume growth is tied to ratings and the expansion of advertisers into some of our newer products like Travel and Cooking.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, I'm not sure how easy this is going to be to answer. But, Ken, you mentioned your team plans to transform the Travel brand. That's a pretty strong statement. Any color you want to give us there? Is there a big hole in lifestyle entertainm
componenttext: And then lastly, I'm not sure how easy this is going to be to answer. But, Ken, you mentioned your team plans to transform the Travel brand. That's a pretty strong statement. Any color you want to give us there? Is there a big hole in lifestyle entertainment programming, where you can reposition the brand or what transformation are you suggesting?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Doug. I think it's really out of our playbook relative to what we've done in the past with our other cable networks, more importantly, HGTV and Food. And I don't think transform is too big a word. I mean, if you look back at when we acquired the Foo
componenttext: Sure, Doug. I think it's really out of our playbook relative to what we've done in the past with our other cable networks, more importantly, HGTV and Food. And I don't think transform is too big a word. I mean, if you look back at when we acquired the Food Network, for example, there was really a transformation there and not only expanding the number of personalities, which John just alluded to. It very much has become a personality-driven network, but building around those personalities to launch other shows. So really encouraged in these early days with Laureen Ong and her team and the opportunities we see. And quite frankly, they were some of the opportunities that we saw back when we went after the Travel Channel. As we say in the business, stay tuned. I think you'll be delightfully surprised at what that network is going to be looking like in the coming days. And by the way, it's not to belittle in any way, shape, or form the success that they're already having with quite a few shows and personalities. But we're very excited about that one, Doug.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Matthew Harrigan, Wunderlich Securities.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Matthew Harrigan, Wunderlich Securities.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, the whole algorithm for advertising is probably going to change over the next few years with eBiz and the broadband, linear TV integration. Can you talk about your approach there? And what would make you feel that you would be a relative win
componenttext: First of all, the whole algorithm for advertising is probably going to change over the next few years with eBiz and the broadband, linear TV integration. Can you talk about your approach there? And what would make you feel that you would be a relative winner? And then secondly, particularly with respect to Travel, can you talk about over-indexing that you're seeing on the HDTV side. Because I think you've mentioned that before as something that's a prospective boon for Travel in particular on a relative basis?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Matthew. Happy to do that. Start with the advertising question, great question, one we think about a lot here. Of course, when you think about our digital assets hgtv.com, foodnetwork.com, those are two of the leading websites in the world in the ho
componenttext: Sure, Matthew. Happy to do that. Start with the advertising question, great question, one we think about a lot here. Of course, when you think about our digital assets hgtv.com, foodnetwork.com, those are two of the leading websites in the world in the home and food categories. In our approach in advertising in upwards of 20% to 30% of our businesses is a complete full circle of linear transforming to non-linear digital advertising that completes the circle, completes the loop if you will for the advertiser to bring in audience from the point of inspiration on TV, to the point of action online or to take action online. Including, in some cases, right down to the transaction in terms of the marketplace section of hgtv.com. But it's an evolving puzzle. It gets more interesting every day. We're introducing some interesting iPad and iPhone apps. And we'll be, in the fall, be introducing a page subscription app for iPad on Food Network and experimenting in driving revenue through the subscription side of the business as well. But we think we have a distinctive advantage with these categories. The way we think about it is that the degree to which we focus, and focus on our consumers within these categories and understand where our consumers are headed and how they're using various devices and how they're using our information for the betterment in the Home and Food category. Then we can stay a step ahead of them by focusing intently on consumer behavior within our categories. To us, that's actually our core competency as a business. We pay a lot of attention to it. In terms of travel over-indexing on hi-def, it's something that we came to understand after acquiring the network. I think, obviously, it's such a well-produced network in so many ways and the visual effects of series like No Reservations with Anthony Bourdain as an example. I think this helps drive the HD usage. And we've seen an expansion of HD for us on DirectTV recently to improve our overall percentage of HD as a result.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of Barry Lucas, Gabelli and Company.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Barry Lucas, Gabelli and Company.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Couple of real quick ones for John. John, maybe go to the extent you can and talk a little bit more about pricing. Not just the upfront, but how did you position Travel, since you added new advertisers, you're cross selling, and that seems to smack a litt
componenttext: Couple of real quick ones for John. John, maybe go to the extent you can and talk a little bit more about pricing. Not just the upfront, but how did you position Travel, since you added new advertisers, you're cross selling, and that seems to smack a little bit sometimes of discounting. So what's the philosophy, or how do you approach trying to broaden the advertising base of Travel versus the rest of the group?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Barry, happy to do that, and certainly not discounting at all. Our goal with Travel is really three prong: Improve the ratings, improve the pricing and as a result, drive the top line as best as we can. The team at Travel is doing a very good job in
componenttext: Sure, Barry, happy to do that, and certainly not discounting at all. Our goal with Travel is really three prong: Improve the ratings, improve the pricing and as a result, drive the top line as best as we can. The team at Travel is doing a very good job in the interim as they're developing their further programming strategy. To Ken's point, driving ratings today. We saw a 26% growth in primetime, 25 to 54 adult impressions coming out of July. So it's one of the fastest growing networks today based on our ability to cross promote the network. And Laureen Ong and her team driving success there everyday. And then our ad sales team is doing what they do with HGTV and Food. And that's we're selling something beyond just the access to commercial pods but rather we're selling a relationship with the category. Similarly, we do that with Food and HGTV, and our ad sales teams are developing specific advertising products that fit well in the Travel category that are attractive to the vertical advertisers that we have. The reputation for really delivering for them. And then Travel also is working on developing its website, so that we can complete that 360 experience as we do in the Home and Food category to really help support our CPMs and create -- in essence at the end of the day, create a much more highly-qualified audience, more upscale, younger and more intentional about buying products within the network itself.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: One more, if I may, maybe for Joe. Given the experience and history with the Indian market, what gives you any degree of confidence that you can bring something successful into a conclusion there, Joe?
componenttext: One more, if I may, maybe for Joe. Given the experience and history with the Indian market, what gives you any degree of confidence that you can bring something successful into a conclusion there, Joe?

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I like to think, we've certainly learned a lot. We have been looking at that market for, I don't know, the better part of two years, while we try to reach a deal that was acceptable with the folks there, with our first party. And I think we learned
componenttext: Well, I like to think, we've certainly learned a lot. We have been looking at that market for, I don't know, the better part of two years, while we try to reach a deal that was acceptable with the folks there, with our first party. And I think we learned enough that we're much more realistic about the shape of the landscape, which by the way, has evolved significantly during those two years. We do think that you can sort of see an inflection point there in terms of expansion of digital cable. And I think once that happens, then people who are on the ground there will benefit from sort of a rising tide. I think the most important thing for us to do is to get our programming there, get the brand known there and get distribution as soon as possible, with a good partner who brings some complementary skills to ours. So I think it's hard to say exactly what the item is that gives me great confidence. But market dynamics there are very promising, and I think the future is very bright. And it's just a very large English-speaking market with a rising middle class, that I think it's going to have quite an appetite for lifestyle programming.

headline: Scripps Networks Interactive, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-09-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] There are no further questions in the queue at this time.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] There are no further questions in the queue at this time.
